Melisa es una mujer de 20 años, vive en la ciudad de Pisco con su pareja y su pequeño hijo, a quienes ama y son su principal razón en la vida, ella es una persona muy amable, trabajadora  entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente Melisa no pudo estudiar una carrera profesional, pero le hubiera gustado mucho poder hacerlo, en sus ratos libres le gusta jugar con su pequeño.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, desde hace tres años Melisa trabaja en su pequeño negocio de confección y costura de ropa, todos los días desde tempranas horas de la mañana inicia su labor, ella puede trabajar un aproximado de 8 horas y cree que le va bien por su dedicación y por el trato amable que brinda a sus clientes.
Melisa se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de una pequeña maquina remalladora semi industrial; de esta manera Melisa podrá realizar todo tipo de costuras, con ello espera poder aumentar sus servicios e incrementar sus ingresos económicos, los cuales le servirán de mucho para que poco a poco pueda ir logrando su sueño de tener su casa propia y darle una buena educación a su pequeño hijo.
texts.en:
Melisa is a 20 year old woman who lives in the city of Pisco with her partner and small child, who she loves and considers to be her primary reason for living.  She is a very friendly, hardworking, and enthusiastic person who has a great desire to succeed.  Sadly, Melisa was not able to study at the university level, but she would have really liked to do so.  In her free time, she really enjoys playing with her little one.

By her own initiative, and with a great deal of effort and dedication, for the past three years, Melisa has had a small business sewing and tailoring clothing.  Every day, she begins work early in the morning, and she works for about 8 hours a day and thinks it is going well because of her dedication and the good treatment that she provides to her customers.

Melisa is very thankful for the lenders at Kiva, since it is thanks to their help that she will be able to make the purchase of a small semi-industrial serging machine.  In this way, Melisa will be able to make all kinds of seams, and with this, she hopes to be able to expand her services and increase her income, which will serve her greatly in moving little by little toward achieving her dream of having her own house and giving a good education to her young son.

loans.use: to buy a semi-industrial serger (sewing machine).

loans.name: Raúl Alejandro

texts.es:
Raúl es un hombre luchador y emprendedor que se rebusca la vida a costa de todo.
El es soltero y vive con su madre y hermanos menores a los cuales debe sostener y sacar adelante. Por esta razón trabaja incansablemente en su video tienda, la cual tiene acreditada cerca su casa. Desde allí reproduce y copia películas que descarga desde internet ya que cuenta con el código y usuario para realizar esta acción.
Sus películas son de buena calidad y sus clientes siempre están satisfechos con el producto que él les vende.
El solicita un préstamo para comprar surtido de frituras y bebidas gaseosas, así podrá ofrecer un mejor servicio y hacer más agradable la visita de sus clientes.
Su principal desafío es la manutención de su familia pues desde siempre ha sido responsable de los ingresos en su hogar.
El sueña con tener otro establecimiento de videos y así generar mayores ganancias, además de poder ofrecer empleo.
texts.en:
Raúl is a hardworking and enterprising man who manages to get by at all costs.  He is single and lives with his mother and younger siblings, whom he is obligated to support and take care of.  For this reason, he works tirelessly in his video store, which he has set up near his home.  From there, he reproduces and copies movies that he downloads from the internet, because he has the code and the username to do so.

His movies are of high quality, and his customers are always satisfied with the product he sells them.

He is asking for a loan to stock up on fried snacks and soda pop.  In this way he will be able to offer better service and make his customers’ visits more agreeable.

His main challenge is supporting his family because he has always been responsible for the household income.  He dreams of having another video store and, in this way, making better earnings.  He would also be able to offer jobs.

loans.use: to buy fried food and soda pop

loans.name: Kely Carolina

texts.es:
Kely es una joven de 23 años de edad, a la que la vida le ha enseñado que para salir adelante se requiere de esfuerzo y disciplina. 

Por lo cual inició un negocio de manicure en la sala de su vivienda atendiendo a las personas del sector. Esta actividad la aprendió gracias a un familiar. 
Por su amabilidad y excelente prestación del servicio esta mujer se ganó el respeto y el aprecio de sus clientes lo que le permitió expandir su negocio y alquilar un local. 

Hoy siente que gran parte de sus sueños se han cumplido porque gracias a su oficio le ha brindado a su hija una mejor calidad de vida. 

En la actualidad se encuentra solicitando un crédito que invertirá en la compra de productos de belleza y en una silla para realizar pedicura y manicura con el propósito de seguir creciendo y convertir su salón de belleza en el mejor de su municipio.

loans.use: compra de productos de belleza y en una silla para realizar pedicura y manicura con el propósito de seguir creciendo

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is an active member of Kabuta ladies in action. Nancy is 32 years old married and has 3 children. Her first loan was USD100 and she paid it very well.

Nancy has a dairy cow, which produces10 litres of milk daily. Currently, the cow is about to give birth and the milk will increase to 20 litres per day. She is also a teacher at Kambwe primary school. She sells her milk to a cooperative society at $28 cents per litre and this will give her $5 per day.

loans.use: Nancy intends to pay school fees for her 2 sons who are in college.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Dorcas would like to pay school fees for her daughter

loans.name: Maria De Jesús

texts.en:
Since she was a kid, Mrs Maria de Jesus was involved with sales – her parents had a grocery store. When she got married, her husband’s income was not enough to cover all household expenses and she decided to start selling clothes and stationary. Maria’s husband passed away 2 years ago. She has seven children, all of them married, and lives with one of her grandsons, who is 18 years old and helps her in her business.

Maria needs $775 to buy merchandise and prepare for children’s day, mother’s day and the end of school break, when sales increase. Maria needs your support to grow her business and is grateful for any help you can give.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria de Jesús desde niña estaba relacionada con las ventas, sus papás tenían una tienda de abarrotes, ya casada, el ingreso que recibía su esposo era insuficiente para solventar los gastos del hogar, por lo que decidió iniciar con la venta de mercería y papelería. Hace dos años Maria quedó viuda, tiene siete hijos, ya todos están casados, actualmente vive con uno de sus nietos, de 18 años, que le ayuda a atender su negocio.

En estos momentos Maria necesita de un préstamo por $ 775 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para surtir su negocio y prepararse para las fechas del día del niño, de las madres y el regreso a clases que es cuando se incrementan las ventas. Ella necesita de tu ayuda para sacar adelante su negocio, y te agradece cualquier apoyo que puedas brindarle.

loans.use: surtir el negocio

loans.name: Yeabu

texts.en: Yeabu C. is thirty-two years old and married with four children.  Her husband migrated to a mining area in Kono, in Eastern Sierra Leone with the hope of getting employed in the mining business, leaving the sole responsibility of the family care to Yeabu.   She runs a small stall business of selling food items like salt, beans, coconut and tomato paste.  With the absence of her husband Yeabu is able to earn enough income to feed her four children.   She is requesting the loan funds to expand her business for better profit. She is determined to keep providing for her family.

loans.use: Increase inventory and diversity of food items for sale in the market

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda is 29 years old and is married to Benjamin, who is 34 years old. Their 9 year old son attends primary school. Benjamin works in agriculture and contributes to the household costs with his earnings from the produce sales. Hilda has a small shop in the municipal market where she also sells used clothing She has been doing this for 7 years. They do not have their own house. They live in their parents house and dream about building their own one day.

Hilda did not have the opportunity to study because her family has few resources. That's why she sacrifices so much day after day so that her son lacks nothing, and has the opportunity to get a university education. She manages an average of 20 clients she attends to daily, as well as occassional clients. She will use the loan to buy merchandise to stock the store, such as rice, sugar, noodles, flour, cheese, cooking oil, etc. This will allow her to improve her shop and be able to attract a greater number of customers.

Hilda tiene 29 años, está casada desde hace 3 años con Benjamín que tiene 34 años. Ambos tienen un hijo de 9 años que está estudiando el 4to. Año de la primaria. El esposo de Hilda es agricultor y aporta a los ingresos del hogar con las ganancias que obtiene de la venta de los productos que saca de sus cultivos. Hilda posee una pequeña despensa que funciona en el mercado municipal de Itá y además vende ropas usadas. Hace 7 años que se dedica a la misma actividad. Aún no posee casa propia, vive en la de sus padres y sueña con construirla algún día. Comenta que no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar debido a que provenía de una familia de escasos recursos, es por eso que día a día se sacrifica para que a su hijo no le falte nada y tenga la oportunidad de acceder a una educación universitaria. Maneja un promedio de 20 clientes que atiende por día que son fijos y otros tantos ocasionales. Desea acceder a un préstamo para comprar mercaderías como: arroz, azúcar, fideo, harina, queso, aceite, etc. para surtir mejor su despensa y así poder atraer una mayor cantidad de clientela a la misma.

loans.use: To buy oil, sugar, cheese, noodles, etc. for her store.

loans.name: Najmiddin

texts.ru:
Najmiddin’s business runs smoothly – he sells household goods at the central market in Kanibadam. Najmiddin is 25 years old and got married recently. His parents and his younger brother help him with his business. 6 months ago Najmiddin received a loan from MicroInvest and rented another shop where his brother sells goods. Najmiddin travels to buy goods. In his newly open shop Najmiddin added new types of goods: gift sets. They are very popular items and bring good profit. Currently, he is planning to add to his assortment kitchenware and is requesting a new loan.

Translated from Russian by Jamilya & Keith Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

У Начмиддина хорошо поставленный бизнес – он продает хозяйственные товары на центральном рынке г. Канибадама. Начмиддину 25 лет и недавно он женился. В его бизнесе ему помогают отец с матерью, а также его младший брат. Получив полгода назад займ в Микроинвест он арендовал еще один магазинчик где торгует его брат. За товаром ездит сам Начмиддин. В новом магазинчике он внедрил новые виды товаров – подарочные наборы. Все это пользуется спросом, и прибыль остается хорошая. Сейчас он собирается добавить в ассортимент штучную посуду и поэтому хочет получить новый займ.

loans.use: To purchase kitchenware.

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es:
We find Roxana doing her daily work of making jackets and gloves; she learned the beautiful art thanks to her older sister Norma's teaching her, and since then, with much creativity and patience she makes her beautiful items of clothing in her small shop, beneath her watchful eyes and support of her dear mother and sister. After five years of craftsmanship she acquired two weaving machines, but it is still insufficient to meet the large number of orders that she receives daily.

This 27 year old young mother is asking for a loan in order to be able to purchase a large quantity and variety of raw material (wool) in order ot make her beautiful garments. The wish of this hard-working mother of a 10 month old baby is to be able to export her creations to neighboring countries, and above all, to increase her income in order to be able to remodel her humble home which she bought recently with the help of her husband José, who works as a messenger for the Banco del Trabajo. We support this enthusiastic mother who with talent and effort, wishes to improve her family's future.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Encontramos a Roxana realizando su trabajo cotidiano de confección de chompas y guantes; ella aprendió este bello arte gracias a la enseñanza de su hermana mayor Norma y desde entonces con mucho creatividad y paciencia confeccionan sus hermosas prendas de vestir en su pequeño taller bajo las atentas miradas y apoyo de su querida madre y hermana.Después de cinco años de haberse dedicado permanentemente a este oficio ha adquirido dos máquinas de tejer, pero aún es insuficiente para cumplir con la gran cantidad de pedidos que recibe diariamente.

La solicitud de esta joven madre de 27 años de edad servirá para que pueda adquirir mayor cantidad y variedad de materia prima (lana) para la confección de sus hermosas prendas. El deseo de esta laboriosa madre de un bebé de diez meses es porque desea exportar sus confecciones a los países vecinos y sobre todo para incrementar sus ingresos a fin de poder refaccionar su humilde casita que compró hace poco con ayuda de su esposo José, quien se desempeña como mensajero en el Banco del Trabajo.Apoyemos a esta madre entusiasta que con talento y esfuerzo desea salir adelante con su familia.

loans.use: Purchase a large quantity and variety of raw materials to make her clothing items

loans.name: Irada

texts.en: Irada (her brother is pictured) was born in 1967. She and her brother sell apples and dates. They have been in this business for 4 years. Now Irada needs a loan of $850 to buy additional fruits for to increase their  sales.

loans.use: To buy fruits to sell

loans.name: Nasuti C(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Joyce, Beatrice, Jennifer and Christine are poultry farmers. With the extra business profits, Joyce wants to pay school fees for her children and improve her home. Cissy has a retail shop and wants to use the loan to increase stock in her shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feeds.

loans.name: Yam

texts.en:
Mrs. Yam L. and her husband have been married since 1993. They have six children; four sons and two daughters. Four of their children are studying in the local school and the youngest two stay at home. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. L. has been raising pigs and growing a vegetable garden for over ten years. She grows papayas, eggplant and tomatoes on her farm. Her husband, Mr. Khem You, is a construction worker and a part time fisherman.

She is requesting a loan for the second time in the amount of $400 to reconstruct the stairs of her home.

loans.use: To reconstruct stairs in the home

loans.name: Huklla Llamkasun Group

texts.en:
“Huklla Llamkasun” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project which provides its credit with educational services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations, being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 6,000 – 17,000 ft above sea level). People who live there also face the cold, difficulty growing crops, and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “Huklla Llamkasun” is located in the community of Añancusi in the district of Acoria, province of Huancavelica. The translation of the Quechua-name of the group is “Let´s work as if we were one”. The main activities of the population are growing tropical fruits at lower altitudes and corn, potatoes and wheat at higher altitudes. At still higher altitudes, the people are dedicated to raising bulls and cows, with alpacas and lamas at the highest altitudes. But the size of the community and its (limited) access to public transport has brought more commerce to the village; every Tuesday there is a local market where people sell and buy most of what they need.

This bank has been formed recently by 17 female borrowers and therefore has no history yet…. It has only just started to create history in its community! The expectations working with FINCA Peru are very clear: increase business and save. For all members, the main use of the savings they will be generating from now on is for investing in their business or for the education of their children, whether it is buying school uniforms, supplies, books or even to pay the fees for entering primary or secondary school.

Although many women dedicate their time to similar businesses, they require different loan amounts because of the differences in the size of the business they run …. The loans range from 200 soles, 300 soles, up to 500 soles; the total of the loans of the 17 members is 5,400 soles (US$ 1925).

One of the group members, Lucila R. Nolberta, sells fruit at local markets. Another business she runs is raising small cattle. As is the case in most families, besides her business, she dedicates most of her time to the cultivation of potatoes, wheat, and oca (a root vegetable), which she uses for home consumption. With her 200 soles loan she will be able to buy more fruits. When asked about her future, she tells us that her dream is the education of her children so they can be professionals and go on studying. She simply wants to make her life and that of her family better. With her (future) savings she plans to buy more chickens and pigs, to sell when they have grown big.

Juliana D. Marín, who sells clothes and shoes in her small shop, tells us a slightly different story. Like Lucila, Juliana grows potatoes, wheat, and other crops for home consumption. With her loan of 500 soles, she will be able to buy more merchandise for her business. With more merchandise, she will be able to earn a little more and therefore save more. Her dream for the future is to live a good life with her family and her children. Her expectations in working with FINCA Peru are to learn to work harder and be more responsible.

loans.use: expanding their various small businesses

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira is a popular and admired woman in her family, with a lot of insistence and effort she has successfully concluded her Masters studies, but because of work opportunities in her country she could not practice her profession, because of this she has decided to seek another method of generating her own income and support her husband with the expenses of their home and the education of their 2 adorable children that she diligently cares for by selling clothing. The desire of Elvira and her husband Hermenegildo who works as a professor in a modest school that is far away from the city of Juliaca is to finish renovations on their house; this will give them security and peacefulness; but now Elvira seeing the movement that exists in her business, she hopes to generate more earnings with this investment and bring tranquility to her family. With your contribution you will allow her family to live in an environment full of tranquility and wellbeing.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Elvira es una dama muy popular, querida y admirada en su entorno familiar y laboral, con mucho empeño y esfuerzo ha concluido con mucho éxito sus estudios supriores de maestra, pero por falta de oportunidades laborales en su país no puede ejercer su profesión, por esa razón decidió buscar la manera de generar sus propios ingresos económicos y apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de su hogar y la educación de sus 2 adorables hijos que a pesar de su corta edad la apoyan diligentemente en su negocio de venta de ropa.El deseo de Elvira y su esposo Hermenegildo quien trabaja como profesor en una humilde y lejana escuelita de la ciudad de Juliaca es terminar de refaccionar su casita, pequeña morada que hicieron construir con muchas ilusiones de acoger, brindarles seguridad y tranquilidad a sus retoños; pero ahora doña Elvira viendo el movimiento que existe en su negocio desea aumentar el monto de inversión con el fin de generar mayores ingresos para la tranquilidad de su familia.“Con tu contribución permitirás que esta familia viva en un ambiente lleno de tranquilidad y bienestar”

loans.use: An increase of capital for her work to offer a better quantity of clothing

loans.name: Corazon De Oro I Group

texts.es:
The women that make up the Corazon de Oro I group are from a town called El Jaibalito located on the shores of Atitlan Lake. El Jaibalito is a small town located on a very steep hill. Almost all homes are located on the mountain slope. This small town is not connected to other neighboring towns by any roads due to the mountainous terrain and the volcanoes, which make it difficult to build a road. You can only reach the town by boat.

Usually when a town is isolated the local culture remains intact and this is the case with El Jaibalito. The women mainly speak Maya-Tzutujil, and as you can see in the photo they wear their traditional garb. The lack of exposure to other cultures inhibits the townspeople when they encounter a “foreigner.” The meeting between the women and myself was very funny. They spend the entire interview laughing and it was a very entertaining moment.

All the women that belong to this group are weavers. They are going to invest their loan in the purchase of raw materials and different colored threads. With this thread they are gong to make beautiful traditional costumes using ancient waist loom techniques. The women in the region of Atitlan are taught how to weaved by their mothers at the age of nine years old.

The women believe the loan is useful because it will help them buy a large quantity of thread and with this they will be able to make more huipiles (embroidered blouses), whether their clients pay them on time or not.

This group of women is always smiling and they deserve an opportunity to succeed as entrepreneurs. Through this loan they can get this opportunity.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy Juárez, Kiva volunteer.

Las señoras que conforman el grupo Corazón de Oro I vienen de un pueblo llamado “el Jaibalito” ubicado a las orillas del Lago Atitlán. El Jaibalito es un pueblo muy pequeño que está ubicado en una cuesta muy, pero muy, empinada. Casi todas las casas están ubicadas en las laderas de una montaña. Este pequeño pueblo no está conectado por carreteras con los otros pueblos vecinos ya que la complicada geografía de las montañas y volcanes no permite que una carretera sea construida. Solo se puede llegar al pueblo por medio de lanchas.

Usualmente cuando un pueblo esta aislado, la cultura del lugar permanece intacta, y el Jaibalito no es la excepción. Las mujeres hablan mayormente el Maya-Tzutujil y, como se ve en la foto, ellas visten sus bellos trajes tradicionales. La falta de exposición a otras culturas inhibe a la gente cuando ellas ven a un “extranjero”. El encuentro entre las señoras y mi persona fue muy gracioso. Las mujeres se pasaron toda la entrevista riéndose. Ese momento fue muy ameno.

Todas las señoras que pertenecen a este grupo son tejedoras. Ellas van a invertir su crédito en la compra de materia prima, hilos de distintos colores. Con estos hilos, ellas van a elaborar bellos trajes tradicionales utilizando la técnica antigua de telar de cintura. Las mujeres en la región de Atitlán aprenden, de sus madres, a tejer desde que tienen nueve años de edad.

Las mujeres piensan que el crédito si les sirve porque les ayuda a comprar mayor cantidad de hilo y con este poder elaborar más huipiles, independientemente si sus clientes le pagan o no a tiempo.

Este grupo de señoras que cargan una bella sonrisa todos lados merecen una oportunidad de salir adelante como empresarias. Por medio de este crédito esta oportunidad se les puede brindar.

loans.use: To purchase thread for making traditional costumes

loans.name: Puth

texts.en: Puth M., 44, lives in Siem Reap Province with her husband and two children. She works with her husband selling firewood, and their combined income is typically $8 each day. Many in Cambodia are facing economic difficulties with rising inflation making the price of food, especially rice, soar. Puth M., though, has an entrepreneurial mindset and sees how she can expand her business through the purchase of a trailer to transport the firewood. She has asked CREDIT for a loan of $500 to make this investment, which she believes will both  increase her daily income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to transport firewood.

loans.name: Koffi Albert

texts.fr:
Mr. Koffi Albert Akapo was born on December 12th, 1981, in the village of Tsevie, not far from the city of Lome in Togo. His is single and takes care of one child. He is an electrician by training, however, lacking the resources to open his own workshop, he started purchasing used equipment which he repaired and resold to the market. Over time, he became specialized in the sale of electronic equipment. Since 2007, he has enjoyed combining the business of selling electronic equipment, along with a range of general grocery supplies. After careful study, he is requesting his first loan to purchase groceries supplies, including milk, tomatoes, soap etc.

Translated from French by Dave Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

Le 12 décembre 1981 naissait monsieur A. Koffi Albert dans un village non loin de la ville de Lomé au TOGO, Tsévié. Il est célibataire avec un enfant à la charge. C’est un électronicien de formation. Mais n’ayant pas les moyens d’ouvrir son atelier, il a commencé à acheter des appareils d’occasion qu’il répare et revend sur le marché. Petit à petit il a fini par se spécialiser dans la vente d’appareils électroniques. Ayant pris goût au commerce, il a associé à la vente d’appareils électroniques, la vente des divers d’alimentation générale ce qui lui réussi depuis 2007. Après une étude qu’il effectua récemment, monsieur A. demande ce premier prêt pour augmenter son fonds de roulement afin d’acheter des produits d’alimentation générale tels que lait, tomate, savon...

loans.use: Purchase of basic grocery items

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Natri

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Natri has a very simple cage, with bamboo construction and woven coconut tree leaves as ceiling to breed pigs. She has started the business since she got married with I Made Peleng. Up to now, Ni Nyoman Natri is still running the business, for it has been able to give additional income that Improve their family’s economic condition. After their children got married, Ni Nyoman Natri only lives with husband.

Ni Nyoman Ratri runs the business enthusiastically. She manages the breed in between with her activity managing the farmland. Before earning loan from Dinari, she ran the business with only IDR 400,000, which was deployed to purchase 2 local piglets that have been raised traditionally. Limited capital has sometimes forced Ni Nyoman Natri to sell the pigs before they are mature. She has to do that because her family sometimes need extra money, that she cannot purchase fodder for the pigs. The price of fodder and piglets are quite expensive.

With the motivation to improve the business, Ni Nyoman Natri proposed loan from Dinari. She plans to use the loan to purchase piglets that will be raised to reproduce piglets that in the future she can sell piglets for other breeders. She is confident that the loan, combined with her hard working, will be very useful, that she will be able to increase her income.

Translated form Indonesian by Hestyana DK, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Nyoman Natri memiliki kandang yang sangat sederhana , dinding bambu dan atap daun kelapa yang di anyam. Ni Nyoman Natri telah memulai usaha beternak babi sejak menikah dengan I Made Peleng. Sampai saat ini Ni Nyoman Natri masih tetap menekuni usaha itu karena dengan beternak babi ia bisa mendapat tambahan penghasilan untuk membantu pendapatan keluarga. Ni Nyoman Natri tinggal berdua dengan suaminya setelah anaknya menikah. Ni Nyoman Natri sangat berantusias untuk mengembangkan usaha ternak babi yang sedang di tekuni. Hal ini dilakukannya untuk mengisi waktu luang sebelum dan setelah bekerja sebagai petani di kebun miliknya. Sebelum mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari, Ni Nyoman Natri hanya mengandalkan modal Rp. 400.000.- untuk membeli 2 ekor bibit babi lokal yang di pelihara secara tradisional. Dengan modal yang sangat terbatas itu sering kali Ni Nyoman Natri harus menjual ternaknya sebelum waktu panen karena kebutuhan keluarga yang mendesak atau tak sanggup membeli pakan. Apalagi saat ini harga bibit dan pakan cukup tinggi. Kerja keras dan kemauan yang kuat untuk mengembangkan usahanya , Ni Nyoman Natri melakukan pinjaman di Dinari yang di pergunakan untuk membeli bibit Induk sehingga kedepan tak lagi membeli bibit bahkan bisa menyediakan bibit untuk peternak yang lain . Dengan tambahan modal itu kini Ni Nyoman Natri merasa lebih tenang dan yakin akan mendapat hasil yang lebih baik dari pada sebelumnya.

loans.use: To purchase breeder

loans.name: Madeleyne

texts.es:
La señora Madeleyne Rodríguez U. tiene treintaiocho años  y vive en la calle soledad sin número del distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta  tercer año de primaria,  ya no siguió estudiando porque sus padres eran negociantes y ella tenía que ayudar en el negocio dedicándose al cuidado de los animales.
Se casó de diecisiete años con el señor Miguel Carranza Castillo y tienen tres hijos los que todavía son estudiantes.
Su negocio consiste en la compraventa de animales, reses, cerdos y ovejas, los compran de las chacras y los venden en las plazas pecuarias a mejor precio. Su negocio se ubica en las plazas pecuarias de Julcán y Otuzco.
Recuerda con gratitud que Manuela Ramos le otorgó un préstamo de 300 soles por primera vez, con lo que compró productos para una bodega que tenía en ese tiempo. “Se vendía mucha golosina porque mi casa está muy cerca de la escuela” comenta Madeleyne. El préstamo lo devolvió en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/ 2000 soles, el cual será pagado en 4 cuotas, comprará dos terneros, para ser vendidos en la plaza pecuaria de Julcán.
Tiene un gran sueño y es el de conocer Europa.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Trabajo desde hace aproximadamente diez años.
texts.en:
Madeleyne Rodríguez U. is 38 years old and lives on Soledad Street in the district of Mache, province of Otuzco, department of La Libertad, Perú. She studied up to third grade of primary school, but did not continue her studies because her parents were merchants and she had to help out in their business by taking care of the animals. She married Miguel Carranza Castillo when she was 17 years old and they have three children who are students. Their business is the purchase and sale of animals: cows, pigs and sheep. They buy them from farms and sell them at livestock markets for a higher price. The business is located in the livestock markets at Julcán and Otuzco. She remembers with gratitude the first time that Manuela Ramos granted her a loan for 300 soles, with which she bought products for a small general store she had at that time. "A lot of sweets were sold because my house was very close to a school," says Madeleyne. That loan was repaid in four months. With this loan for S/2000 soles, which will be repaid in four payments, she will buy two calves to be resold in the livestock market at Julcán. She has a huge dream and that is to go to Europe. She has belonged to the Working Women Communal Bank for approximately 10 years.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy livestock (two calves).

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-five-year-old, Mary P. from Mwanza. She is married with three children, between the ages of six and thirteen. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants because they are orphans.

Mary has been running an African print cloth shop since 2002. She works at the business for sixteen hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her sister. Mary currently earns about US$ 200 per month from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$ 400 in order to buy more African print cloth. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Mary thanks you for supporting her!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more African print cloth for re-sale

loans.name: Thi Yen's Group

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Yến năm nay 37 tuổi Ms 01050021 là một phụ nữ năng động và biết học hỏi mô hình chăn nuôi ở địa phương để vận dụng vào mô hình chăn nuôi của gia đình mình. Hàng ngày ngoài việc chăn nuôi lợn, chị còn đi làm công nhân của nhà máy gạch, công việc tuy bận rộn nhưng chị luôn giành thì gian chăm sóc và dạy 2 con học bài. Còn chồng chị đi làm thuê nên mức thu nhập của gia đình chị cũng khá ổn định từ 160.000đ đến 180.000đ/ ngày. Chị và nhóm đã tham gia vay vốn qua 2 chu kỳ và hoàn trả rất tốt, chu kỳ này chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để đầu tư vào việc chăn nuôi lợn.
Trong nhóm chị có các thành viên sau :
 Chị Nguyễn Thị Bích Ms 01050014 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để kinh doanh sắt.
 Chị Lê Thị Mến Ms 01050019 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để kinh doanh thóc, gạo.
 Chị Trần Thị Hải Ms 01050020 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để đi chợ bán hàng hoa quả và mua gạo nấu rượu.
 Chị Nguyễn Thị Ngọc Ms 01050022 vay mức 4.256.000VNđ để kinh doanh hàng kính mắt thời trang.
 Chị Nguyễn Thị Hậu Ms 01050023 vay mức 4.256.000VNđ để đi chợ buôn bán thịt lợn.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Yen (ID Number 01050021), 37 years old, is an active woman. She is abL. to learn from the local pig rearing model and apply it at home. Besides rearing pigs, she also works in a brick factory. Even though she is very busy, she still sets aside time to take care of and help her children with their school work. Her husband is a hired worker, so her family's daily income is quite stabL. at 160,000VND to 180,0000VND. Her group has borrowed twice and repaid successfully. This time, she would like to borrow 4,704,000VND to invest in rearing pigs. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. N. Thi Bich (ID Number 01050014), borrows 4,704,000VND to buy and sell iron.
  • Mrs. L. Thi Men (ID Number 01050019), borrows 4,704,000VND to buy and sell rice.
  • Mrs. T. Thi Hai (ID Number 01050020), borrows 4,704,000VND to buy and sell fruits, as well as to purchase rice to make wine.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Ngoc (ID Number 01050022), borrows 4,256,000VND to buy and sell fashion sunglasses.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Hau (D Number 01050023), borrows 4,256,000VND to buy and sell pork.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rearing pigs

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Nary T., 46, and her husband, Mr. Ny Tem, 47 who live in a small village along National Road Number Two about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1985 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. The elder son is a photographer and the other children attend school.

Nary has been selling grocery items for fifteen years. She buys them from Takhmao market for re-sale at her home. Her husband has been selling fruit for ten years. He buys the fruit from the market in Phnom Penh for re-sale at Takhmao market. Nary can generate about US$ 4 per day in profit and her husband can earn about US$ 7.50 a day in profit.

Nary is applying for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a camera for her son for his photography business.

loans.use: To purchase a camera for her son's  business

loans.name: Tapuni

texts.en: Tapuni F., 61, is married with 4 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about $125 USD).  SPBD loans are Tapuni’s only access to capital because she does not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase frying pan, sacks of flour, sacks of sugar, yeast and cooking oil for her pancake business.

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Som S. is 36 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a garment factory worker and earns US$ 2.50 per day. Her husband Leng Horn, 39, pictured here, works growing vegetables and selling them at the market near his house. On average, he makes US$ 3 a day. This couple has four children; three are in school and one is a garment worker. This couple would like to purchase a water pump, fertilizer, and seeds to expand their cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump, fertilizer, and seeds

loans.name: Bushra M. Afzal Chouhan Group

texts.en:
Bushra Baji is a very hardworking and caring lady. She is 46 years old, married and a citizen of a historical place named Yadgar, Pakistan for the past 17 years. Her husband's name is M. A. C., who runs a grocery shop in the community. She supports her husband by sewing clothes because inflation is increasing day by day and it’s tough to manage the household by one person. She is the mother of five kids: two sons and three daughters. All of her kids are in school located near their house.  She pays the school fees for her kids with the money she earns from sewing clothing. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is applying again for a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

She is a group leader for women in her locality. Zareena Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Kishwar Sultana Baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Khursheed Begum baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (switches, wires and tube lights) to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The member's mutually guarantee each loan will be paid back. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca A. is 35 years old. She is a divorced mother of one daughter and two sons. One of her children is in junior high school while the rest are in the basic school. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a small farming community called Nkwateng in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Her children are living with their father in Accra, the capital city.

The major occupation of the residents of Nkwateng, the men in particular, is farming. Rebecca, however, sells beverages in her community. She prepares porridge, tea, wheat porridge, rice porridge and oats, and fries eggs and popcorn. She sells from the afternoons until evening. She sells on a table by the roadside.

Rebecca procures her materials from Kumasi at cost-effective prices. She has been in business for four years. Rebecca says she wants a loan to buy ingredients in bulk. It is her dream to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To procure ingredients

loans.name: Dios Es Mi Pastor 5 Group

texts.en:
This group of five is the newest addition to the Dios es mi Pastor (God is my Shepherd) Bank of Hope in San Pedro de Macoris. This is their first loan for their micro enterprises and they all believe it'll be a great help to their business activities. 
Joselin M. is the group representative. She started her business selling clothes, but now is looking to expand by starting a nail salon with this micro loan. She will use the loan amount to buy the materials to do acrylics in her small booth, which will be located at her house. She will also buy the machine used to polish the nails and make them look smooth and natural. She will also use a small portion of the loan to buy pants, blouses and undergarments for her clothing clientele. She believes her hard work will help her achieve her goals and provide a better life quality for her children.
Please help us support the creativity and determination of these ladies. Thank you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase a nail polishing machine and acrylic nails materials

loans.name: Nelbi

texts.es:
La sra. NELBI, nació en la provincia de chincheros en la comunidad de cruz pata, ubicado a 1 hora de la ciudad del Cusco en transporte público.

La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio, ella tiene una combi y hace transporte público en la ruta Cusco, también es negociante, la socia compra mercadería de todo tipo, ropa, productos de limpieza, y demás para la venta al público en general, la socia solicita el préstamo para viajar y comprar mercadería.

La sra. Nelbi está muy agradecida con este medio y reitera su compromiso de cumplir con el pago total de su préstamo en el tiempo programado.
texts.en:
NELBI was born in Chincheros province, in the village of Cruz Pata, located 1 hour by public transportation from the city of Cusco.

She alternates her responsibilities at home with the business. She owns a "combi" (a small bus or van) and provides transporation services on the Cusco road. She's a merchant, too, buying goods of all kinds--clothes, cleaning products and so on--to resell. She is applying for a loan so that she can travel and buy goods.

Nelbi is very grateful to have this means to borrow funds and commits to repaying the loan in the agreed-upon time.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en: Mrs. Ethel D. has been selling snacks since her childhood. In addition, she also cultivates a little farmland, producing corn and bananas. Her husband is a farmer. She is 32 years old and resides in Guba, Clarin, Mis. Occ. Ethel has been a very active, hardworking member of Paglaum MPC since 2005. As a member of the PDP-LP program of Paglaum MPC, she also enjoys the benefits of savings and insurance. This loan will be used to purchase additional ingredients for her snacks and a small part of it is for fertilizer for their farm. She aspires to give her children a better future, make a mini cafeteria, and expand her business into other areas.

loans.use: Capital for a snack vending business and to buy fertilizer for a farm

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is thirty-three years old and married with four children. She sells secondhand clothes. She hopes for a loan to purchase more secondhand clothes to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Allah Rakhi Muhammad Aslam Group

texts.en:
Zahida baji wants a loan to buy tea to sell.

Majeedan baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business.

Shamim baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (colored thread, beads and clothes) for her decorative-embroidery business.

Kishwar baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.

Allah rakhi baji is the group leader of these above mentioned ladies. These all are very hardworking ladies. They run their own businesses to support their families.

Allah rakhi baji runs her decorative-embroidery business. She takes orders from her neighbors and from the clothes shops. She completes each dress in five to ten days and saves her income and uses it on need. She is married to M. A. who is a blacksmith and makes iron rods and iron chains. He has been doing this business for the past five years. She is applying for a loan to buy iron for her husband’s blacksmith business.

loans.use: To buy iron for her husband to make iron items to sell

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
A. Zafar is 38 years old and married with 3 children. Zafar has successful business of selling flour at the local market of Shahrituz town. Zafar sells an assortment of good quality flours. Zafar has been engaged in this type of business for 3 years, and in that period he become a very successful entrepreneur. While his business is doing very well, he sees an opportunity to increase his sales by maintaining a larger inventory of goods. Therefore, Zafar is requesting a loan of $1200 USD to purchase more goods for resale.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged its already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase flour to sell

loans.name: Daniel Nyantika

texts.en:
Daniel O. is 51 years old and married to Christine. Together, they have six children. Daniel runs a butcher shop in the Nyamusi Market Center in Nyanza Province.

This will be Daniel's second loan from KADET.  He used his first loan to construct his own butcher shop, and the profits from the shop have enabled him to meet his family's needs. He has been able to employ one more person, who assists him in the daily operations of the business.

Daniel hopes that this loan will enable him to expand his business and even to open another butcher shop at a nearby market.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To increase butchery stock by purchasing more bulls and goats

loans.name: Gismala

texts.en:
Gismala R. is currently in the business of selling various items in her shop such as, sweets, toothpaste, toothbrushes, etc., and she is requesting a loan to purchase more goods to sell. Gismala is 49 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has three children who attend school. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar and stock crates of beer to sell. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell at her shop

loans.name: Lydiah

texts.en:
Lydiah K. is a single mother of two grown-up children, Muthoni and Mwangi. She is 49 and in the business of poultry-keeping. She has been a poultry farmer for two years.

Lydiah learned about KADET through a marketing activity by the officers and is glad to be accessing her first KADET loan. With the money, she plans to buy chicken feed and chicken drugs and to pay for the labor of an employee tending to the chickens. Lydiah supplements her income through rental houses she owns in Miritini and is also a dealer in scrap metals.

Her dream is to one day be able to rear a thousand chicken or more.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to  relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: Buying chicken feed and chicken drugs and to pay for labor

loans.name: Jesus Teresa

texts.es:
La señora Teresa pertenece al Banco Comunal “San Juan D. Tahuaco”  que esta ubicado en la comunidad D. San Juan D. Tahuaco del distrito D. Yunguyo, Provincia D. Chucuito, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 59 años D. edad, estado civil casada y es madre D. 04 hijos y estudio primaria completa, vive en la comunidad D. San Juan D. Tahuaco.

La señora trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace varios años, se retiro un ciclo es una D. las socias fundadoras,  con un préstamo inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles  para la compra D. ganado menor. 

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo D. S/. 3000.00 Nuevos soles, con este préstamo la señora va a comprar ganado mayor para engorD..

Su mayor deseo es seguir trabajando.

A ella le gustan los ahorros.

loans.use: Para la compra de ganado vacuno.

loans.name: Ada Luz

texts.es:
la sra. ADA LUZ F. F.. se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva, su producto lo vende de manera domiciliar y ambulante en diferentes comunidades y cacerios circunvecinos a Villa Santa, ella es madre soltera y tiene 1 hijo esto la obligo a buscar cómo poder conseguir dinero para dar la crianza a su hijo, ahora ella ya tiene su negocio y lo mas importante es que a sabido ganarse clientela, ella aspira a que sus clientes igual su negocio sea cada dia mas y mas grande para poder brindarle una buena educación a su hijo.
Ada expreso sentirse muy agradecida y gracias al credito que esta solicitando sus condiciones de vida van a mejorar.
texts.en:
Ada Luz F. F. sells new clothing. She sells from her home and as a traveling saleswoman in different communities and towns neighboring Villa Santa. She is a single mother, and she has one child. This made her look for how she could get money to raise her child. She now has a business. The most important thing is that she has known how to win customers. She hopes that the number of customers she has as well as her business gets bigger and bigger every day. That way she will be able to give her child a good education. Ada feels very grateful. Thanks to the loan that she is asking for her living conditions will improve.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy children's clothes, pants, shirts, jeans, undershirts, and socks

loans.name: Kobilbobo

texts.en:
Kobilbobo is 56 years old and he makes a living buying and selling livestock. He's married with 4 children. Over the years, Kobilbobo has become very knowledgeable about what is required to raise cattle, their feeding, their calving, etc. It should be noted that, in the past, this man endured hard economic times for a while but he's managed to come through thanks to the help provided by IMON International. IMON International has granted loans that Kobilbobo has used to buy calves, the reason, too, that he needs this loan now. The loan will greatly improve Kobilbobo’s income and his family's living standards. 

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of young cattle

loans.name: Edamire

texts.en:
Edamire P. is from the village of I.S. Cruz, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. He is 39 years old. Edamire is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edamire owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Edamire has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately $185 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Edamire joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edamire has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional business capital. Edamire is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the product offering. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Edamire from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mrs. Sinath Noeurn Village Bank Group

texts.en: Thirteen people who live in Damrei Chhlang village in Kandal province make up the Mrs. Sinath N. Village Bank, and all thirteen members will use their loans for different purposes.  Mrs. Sinath N. was selected by the members to be their village bank president.  She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living.  She has not been able to earn enough fR. her farming to support her entire family.  In order to increase her income, Mrs. Sinath N. decided to ask for a loan, which she will combine with her savings so she can buy more land on which she can cultivate rice.  Her husband, Mr. Keng Savuth, is a soldier who earns a small salary.  Mrs. Sinath N. is the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school, while the youngest one is still too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more land for cultivating rice

loans.name: Liberato

texts.en: Liberato owns a tire shop located at the very entrance to the city. He has been running the shop for more than three years. He is married to Maria Ines Flores, with whom he has two children. He has a stable and loyal clientele, who are attracted to his services by the good quality and reliability of his work. He has been a client of the Fundacion Paraguaya since 2008. He needs a loan in order to increase the inventory of goods he offers and improve the quality of his services.

loans.use: To buy goods

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio B. is from the village of Mialen Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is 59 years old. Rogelio is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rogelio owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a tricycle transport services. Rogelio has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Rogelio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogelio has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Rogelio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his existing vehicle to provide a better transportation service

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is 50 years old, divorced and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in central Ghana. Aba works hard as a food vendor to provide for her family. She prepares and sells kenkey, a popular local dish, with fried fish by the roadside. She also sells various other items. Aba buys her maize from nearby farms, and has been in business for more than 25 years. She has applied for a loan to buy maize and other ingredients in bulk to use for her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Maria Luz

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro.
Maria es casada, tiene 40 años y 2 hijos, Maria tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, bebidas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hija, porque ella trabaja en un hostal.
Maria necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de jabón y detergentes.
Los sueños de Maria son terminar de construir su casa y que sus hijos ingresen a la universidad.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Communal Bank “Ccori Ayllu”, which means “Golden Family”. She is 40 years old, married, and has two children. Maria has a store in her home where she sells groceries and beverages. Her daughter helps with managing the store and also works at a hostel.

Maria needs a loan of 600 soles in order to buy soap and detergents. Her dreams are to finish building her house and see her children start college.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soap & detergents

loans.name: Soda

texts.fr: Madame Soda D. habite  Daroukhane dans la localité de Guediawaye. Elle a 49 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 12 et 31 ans. Elle est membre de la caisse de Baye Laye depuis juillet 2006 et a déjà rembourse deux prêts. Cela fait plus de dix ans  qu’elle s’active dans le petit commerce de vente de pain , de beignet et de café  le matin. C’est surtout la rentabilité qui la pousse a choisir cette activité. Ce qui lui  plait surtout dans son activité  c’est l’affluence de la clientèle le matin a la recherche de petit déjeuner. Elle sollicite un crédit de 75 000 frs pour s’approvisionner en mil, niebe,et sucre qui constituent des matières premières pour sa préparation. Le crédit lui assure une certaine autonomie par rapport aux boutiquiers qui souvent la ravitaillaient a crédit et ses bénéfices lui permettent de satisfaire ses besoins personnels
texts.en:
Soda D. lives in Daroukhane in the district of Guediawaye. She is 49 years of age, married and has 7 children between 12 and 31 years old. She has been a member of the microfinance institution of Baye Laye since 2006 and has already paid back two loans. She has had a small business for about ten years and she sells every morning bread, donuts and coffee. She has chosen this business because of the good profit she can make. She likes it because every morning there are many people who buy breakfast. She is requesting a loan of 75 000 frs to buy millet, niebe (a bean spread) and sugar, the main ingredients of the products she sells. The loan will give her some authonomy from her providers that usually sell on credit and the revenue will allow her to pay for her personal needs.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating funds.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Para Triunfar Group

texts.es:
Este grupo del Barrio San Pedro viviendas de la ciudad de  Encarnación  surgió por contacto de una de las integrantes con la fundación.
 Todas las señoras realizan actividades productivas como ser :  venta de mercaderías comestibles, despensa, kiosko,  venta de ropas,  peluquería, fabricación y venta de uniformes de colegio   etc. 
Cada una realiza una actividad independiente para generar sus propios ingresos, así como la señora Felicita A. quien se dedica a la confección de ropas de alta costura para damas, hace vestidos para novias, quinceañeras,  trajes de noches y otros, sus clientes están muy satisfecho con los trabajos de Doña Felicita. El crédito los destinara para la compra de sus herramientas de trabajo.
texts.en:
This Group ("Women united for success") from the neighborhood San Pedro in the city Encarnación was set up when one of its members contacted the microfinance institution Fundación Paraguaya. All the ladies perform productive activities such as selling food products, running a convenience store or a newspaper kiosk, selling clothes, operating a hairdressing salon, tailoring and selling school uniforms, etc. Each has an independent activity to generate her own income. So Ms Felicita A. tailors high fashion dresses for ladies, bridal gowns, dresses for quinceañeras (galas for girls' 15th birthdays), evening dresses and others. Doña Felicita's customers are very satisfied with her work. She will use her loan share to buy work tools and materials.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics, yarns, needles, scissors and buttons

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of weed-killer

loans.name: Andrea Olivia

texts.es:
La Señora Andrea C. M. es casada tiene tres hijos que se encuentran estudiando cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo su negocio esta ubicado a cuadra aledañas al merado central, ambos administran el negocio, empezo su negocio con un capital de C$ 3,0000.00 fueron aporte de su esposo trabajan de lunes a domingo.
Ambos luchan por salir adelante, tiene cuatro años de trabajar con nosotros y le han sacado provecho a estos créditos ya que su calidad de vida es mejor  le dan gracias Dios y al banquito por que siempre los han apoyado para sus inversiones
texts.en:
Andrea C. M. is married and has three children who are in school. Her husband helps her manage her business, which is located a block from the central market. She began her business with a capital investment of C$ 3,0000.00 that was put up by her husband. They work from Monday to Sunday. Both Andrea and her husband struggle hard to get ahead. They have worked with Kiva partner CEPRODEL for four years, and have gotten a lot out of their loans, since their quality of life has improved. They give thanks to God and to their bank because they have always helped them with their investments.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling fast food: tacos, chicken and fries, and soft drinks

loans.name: Cécile Diam

texts.en:
Cécile Diam N. is a forty-year-old married mother of three children. She runs a small business selling fruit and eggs.

Cécile Diam has been a member of the Banc Villageois Thiéckène for nine years and has always paid back her loans on time. With this loan she plans to buy fruit such as melons and oranges as well as chickens for her business.

loans.use: To purchase fruit and chickens.

loans.name: Jovita Montealto Group

texts.en:
Jovita M. is from the village of Tinaclaan, Clarin, Misamis Occdiental. She is 59 years old. Jovita is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jovita is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Jovita owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jovita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jovita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Jovita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jovita is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Jovita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Hargul

texts.en:
Hargul is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan's Kalbadjar region.  She has settled in the Absheron region.

Hargul L. was born in 1962. She is married and has 4 children. Hargul sells cosmetics for a living.  She has been in this business for 6 years and is very experienced in her business  She has a small shop is in Masazir. She is seeking a loan of 2000 AZN to improve her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: sell cornmeal porridge, fresh produce and school supplies.

loans.name: Rwenshama Tukore A, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Friendly and very hardworking K. Hope, a 42 year old married woman with four children, has been running a retail shop business for over three years. Her thriving business caters to the interests of local customers along the Congo border in Rwebinyonyi trading centre, Rukungiri.

Hope has been earning profits amounting to 150,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis. Her main challenge has been, however, having a small amount of stock due to the hindrance of low capital input in her business. Her recourse has, however, been her teaching job salary and also her small fish-selling business.

With Hope’s sense of determination, the sky seems to be the limit in her drive to establish a firm foothold in this retail business and also in her fledgling fish-selling business. This loan will help her to buy more retail items like sugar and soap as well as more fish to match the increasing demand of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more retail merchandise like sugar and soap plus more fish to sell

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en:
N. Sylivia, 21, lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda. Single with one child, for the past year-and-a half Sylivia has had a business selling arts and crafts, including decorative mats that people use to sit on.

To expand her business, Sylivia is requesting a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to buy arts and crafts materials to make more mats, hoping to increase her sales to generate more profits with which to support herself and her child.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Materials to make mats

loans.name: Ana Elizabeth

texts.es: Ana Elizabeth B. R. de 48 años de edad, es una persona soltera, la cual trabaja desde su propia casa de habitación que esta ubicada en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive junto a su hermana quien trabaja como licenciada en computación, y así mismo vive junto a su pequeña sobrina de 3 años de edad. Ana posee su propia tienda en la cual comercializa productos varios como golosinas, pan, papel higiénico, pastillas y algunos tipos de detergentes, a pesar que ya cuenta con 8 años de experiencia, debido a que la mayoría de ganancias son destinas al sostenimiento del hogar, ella invierte muy poco al negocio, por lo que necesita una ayuda para mejorarlo. Es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo a Integral, por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de productos como huevos, jugos, leches, pan, más golosinas en diferentes marcas, de manera que sus clientes tengan mayor variedad para escoger y así comprar más. Ana es una persona muy dedicada a lo que hace, es por ello que su mayor deseo es poder crecer en su negocio y así mismo brindar un mejor servicio en el cual sus clientes se sientan cómodas al comprar en su tienda y de esta manera ella pueda mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Ana Elizabeth B. R. is 48 years old and single. She works from her own home, which is located in the Department of San Salvador. Ana lives with her sister, who works as a degreed computer programmer, and her three year old niece.

Ana has her own store where she sells various products such as candy, bread, toilet paper, medicines, and different brands of detergents. Even though she has eight years of experience, most of her earnings go toward maintaining her household. She invests very little in her business, which is why she needs help improving it. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral so that she will have the money necessary to buy large quantities of products such as eggs, juices, milk, bread, and candies of different brands so that her customers will have a wider variety to choose from and want to buy more.

Ana is very dedicated to what she does, which is why she wants to grow her business and provide better service to her customers so that they will feel more comfortable in her store. By making these improvements, she hopes to improve her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Ayeah

texts.en:
Born in 1984, Ayeah L., is married to Mr. Isaac Jam and they have three children who are all younger than 15. Her motivation comes from the difficulties she faced, especially the death of her mother, poor health, her inability to continue education and the destruction of her cassava farm by wild fire. As a consequence of all this, she was unable to educate her children even at primary school level.

Encouraged by GHAPE borrowers she became a member of GHAPE and received her first loan of 40,000CFAF in 2009. Since then she has proven her ability to receive, invest and repay her loan. From previous loans she provided her community with food stuff like beans, corn and Irish potatoes. 
She is proud of her achievements, especially her success in owning and managing her own business. With profits from these loans, she has been paying her children’s school fees. 

With a new loan, she plans to continue in the same line of business. She plans to buy twenty tins of beans for 50,000FCFA, fifteen tins of Irish potatoes for 20,000FCFA, six tins of corn for 15,000FCFA and vegetables for 10,000FCFA  She will provide food stuff to the community and the business will succeed since she has many customers. Her intention is to use the profit to continue to educate her children and to take care of her health and her family. 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy corn, beans, Irish potatoes and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Angelita Del Socorro

texts.es: La señora Angelita es una señora que tiene 3 años de trabajar con ceprodel ella tiene una comideria en su casa la cual está ubicada en la comarca la gloria de este municipio con este negocio y los prestamos que se la ha financiado ha logrado mejorar sus ingresos ya que le ha permitido ir aumentando su casa y lograr tener mejores condiciones para su negocio ya que cuando empezó solamente tenía dos mesas para atender a su clientela actualmente tiene alrededor de 8 mesas donde atiende un aproximado de unas 60 personas por día por lo que con sacrificio y esfuerzo ella  se ha superado
texts.en:
Sra. Angelita is a woman who has partnered with CEPRODEL for three years. She manages a diner out of her home located in the region of La Gloria. Through her business and with the loans she has received, Angelita has been able to improve her income. As a result, she has been able to expand her house and provide better conditions for her business. When she first started, she only had two tables for serving her customers. Now she has eight tables and is able to serve approximately 60 people each day through hard work and sacrifice.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bricks, cement, and iron to make improvements to her home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rosmery

texts.es: El Sra. Rosmery Vive en el Municipio de la Guardia distante 20 km de la ciudad de Santa Cruz de la Sierra, en el barrio el Bajio en casa de sus tíos, nacida  en la provincia Obispo Santisteban, de montero considerada la capital azucarera de Santa Cruz, su actividad principal es venta de ropa y zapatos deportivos de forma ambulante, vende en  los distintos Barrios  de Santa Cruz, se levanta desde muy temprano en la mañana y cada día sale a distintas ferias, es muy trabajadora , su esposo con el cual tiene un hijo en edad escolar, trabaja como empleado en una empresa, el destino del crédito es para comprar ropa de temporada, se siente agradecida con la institución por el apoyo conseguido.
texts.en:
Sra. Rosmery lives in the town of La Guardia, which is 20km from the city of Santa Cruz de La Sierra, and resides at the house of her aunt and uncle in the neighborhood of El Bajio. She was born in Obispo Santisteban, which is considered to be the sugar capital of Santa Cruz. Her main business activity is selling clothes and athletic shoes as a street vendor. Rosmery sells in different neighborhoods throughout Santa Cruz. She wakes up very early each morning so that she can travel to different fairs.

Rosmery is a hard worker. Her husband works as a company employee and together they have a child who is of school age. This loan will be used to buy seasonal clothing. She is grateful to Emprender for its continued support.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seasonal clothing & athletic shoes

loans.name: Jenes

texts.en:
Jenes O. is a 38 year old business lady dealing in mobile phone accessories and repair in Mwembe Tayari, Mombasa. She is married to Evans O., who supplements her income. They have been blessed with three children. Jenes has been in this business for the last ten years and it has been a success.
