Trabaja con el apoyo de dos de sus hijos quienes le ayudan a realizar algunas funciones y de esta manera cumple con su trabajo de manera óptima.  Lo que le gusta de su labor es que puede trabajar en la comodidad de su hogar además de hacerlo en compañía de sus hijos, se siente muy bien haciendo algo que le gustó desde muy joven y que ha ido mejorando con el paso de los años. Afortunadamente le va muy bien gracias a que su taller esta ubicado en una calle muy concurrida y cerca además a un depósito de vehículos lo cual le permite tener permanentemente una clientela muy fluida, espera que su negocio se mantenga con el mismo ritmo de progreso. Este es el crédito número 13 con MFP, está muy contento por el apoyo financiero que le están brindando ya que así se sentirá seguro de avanzar con su trabajo, por otro lado se compromete a continuar pagando puntualmente sus cuotas tal como le programen, está muy feliz de pertenecer a su banco comunal ya que todos son muy responsables y solidarios.
Con el monto solicitado 1500 soles, comprará repuestos para su venta además de algunos materiales para que pueda seguir con su trabajo de vulcanizado.

loans.use: comprará repuestos y piezas de vulcanizado.

loans.name: Beauty And Group

texts.en: Beauty is 45-year-old hailing from Kamrup district of Assam. She is married and has three children two sons and a daughter. Two of them are attending local school in different grades. Beauty's case her weaving started before marriage. She generates income by weaving and it is the main source of income for her. She sells her woven finished products in the village and nearby villagers. She does not want to depend fully on her husband and believes “It is good to work and earn to support each other in a family”. Unfortunately Beauty often cannot afford to buy silk and cotton yarn which delays production. Funds are so limited that she has to wait until a product is sold to buy yarn for the next one. She require a microfinance loan in order to repair the weaving machine and purchase raw materials for her weaving businesses. Beauty has joined with four other women Purnima, Jyostna, Charabanu and Sarala. Together they need a group loan to expand their respective businesses. The loan amount will help these women meet their family's basic needs and cover their children's educational costs. They are grateful to their lenders.

loans.use: To purchase silk and cotton yarn for weaving and increase productivity

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en: Getrude is married and has 3 children; she was born 26 years ago and started business when she was only 16 years of age. She started by selling vegetables from farmers and selling it to customers in Muranga Town. The business to date is doing very well and she has introduced other products, milk and cereals.  She wants to use the loan for paying school fees and keep paying back monthly because her business cannot generate $ 125 at once but rather can generate monthly installments to pay back the loan.

loans.use: Getrude would like to pay school fees for her children and to restock her retail shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Open a fish processing plant

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia T. is 52 years old and a mother of three.  Her husband died six years ago, leaving her without income.  As none of her children have steady employment, Telesia must strive for financial independence to survive.  She grows cocoa and sells roasted, ground cocoa at local markets.  Cocoa grows well in Samoa and is prized for its unique flavor.  Telesia will use loan funds to buy some basic supplies to make her difficult work more productive.  Telesia’s current cocoa sales bring her approximately ST 50 – 60 (about USD 20) a week, and she is anxious to invest in some time-saving equipment that will allow her to bring more cocoa to the market.

loans.use: Buy basic supplies, e.g. knives, gloves, packaging

loans.name: Bartola Siriaco

texts.en:
Bartola Siriaco M. started out working in a “Pica pollo” (a small diner) with her mother ever since she was a little child. She decided to take this loan so she can invest in her establishment. She wants to have clients feel pleased with the ambiance, and attract new customers as well. She also plans to split the loan to buy more food to offer on her menu. Amongst other things she sells chicken, toasts, assorted fruit juices, and fried plantain.

Bartola is married and has 3 children. Her family helps her run the business and prepare the food every day for their customers. The interesting point in this loan is the fact that it will serve to assist the needs (of the women) in a whole family.

loans.use: Invest in establishment

loans.name: Sullaiman

texts.en: Sullaiman T. is the father of four children.  He runs a small business selling plastic sandals and clothes.  The business is the only source of income for the family and Sullaiman would like to expand it.  He is therefore requesting a loan of $200.

loans.use: Expansion of clothing shop

loans.name: Zalia

texts.en:
Zalia has the Maama Katende Shop in Kayunga. She is 42 years old, married, and has 6 children. She has been operating her small general store for 9 years and sells clothes, paraffin and home use products. She is very meticulous about her finances and accounts for every coin she receives, i.e. she has proper accounting of income and expenses.

She hopes to use her loan to purchase posho, sugar, salt and rice in larger quantities to sell as wholesale. Her business, though small, is very well run and she also gets involved in produce buying and selling.

Her dream is to see her children study hard and go on to higher education levels, and to buy a cow and farm to improve her income.

loans.use: To buy more posho, sugar, salt and rice in larger quantities

loans.name: Hanifa Abdula Babú

texts.pt:
Hanifa J. is married and mother of 3 children. She joined the credit program in June 2006 and her first loan was of 6.000mt. She works selling fish and charcoal in Corumana and in Malhapsswene. She is now in the second cycle of the program and requests a loan of 10.000mt to be repaid in 6 months. She plans on increasing her inventory of charcoal.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Hanifa J. é casada e mãe de 3 filhos. Entrou para o programa em Junho de 2006 com um empréstimo de 6.000MT. Vende peixe e carvão em Corumana e em Malhapsswene. Vai para o 2º ciclo e vai tomar 10.000Mt para pagar em 6 meses. Pretende investir o empréstimo na compra e venda de carvão.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Bertha Lidia

texts.es:
Seventeen years ago, Bertha Lidia started to sell clay items out of her house, but an opportunity came to her to obtain a small location very close to the main bus station in her city. This is why she changed locations and started to sell items like backpacks, toys, and other things. Little by little, she started to gain clients who came by her business to buy crafts and clay items.

However, during this season when many people travel to celebrate the holidays, Bertha doesn't have enough assortment to sell new merchandise. This is why she is requesting a credit of $325 that she is willing to repay in 6 months. With this money, Bertha will be able to purchase merchandise to have something to offer her clients. With your help, Bertha will be able to take good care of her 4 kids.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Hace 17 años que Bertha Lidia comenzó a vender artículos de barro fuera de su casa, sin embargo le llegó la oportunidad de conseguir un pequeño local muy cerca de la central de autobuses en su localidad. Es por es que se cambió de local y comenzó a meter artículos como mochilas, juguetes, entre otras cosas. Y poco a poco se está haciendo de clientes que pasan por su negocio y le compran artesanías y productos de barro.

Sin embargo para esta temporada en que muchos salen de viaje para festejar las fechas Bertha no cuenta con surtido suficiente para poder vender mercancía nueva. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $325 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Bertha podrá comprar mercancía para tener algo que ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Bertha podrá sacar adelante a sus cuatro hijos.

loans.use: To buy clay merchandise

loans.name: Maria Danelia

texts.es:
The sale of curds and cream is the business to which Maria Danelia N. R., single and with one school-aged child, dedicates herself to. She has had the business since a young age, starting it after she separated from her husband and had to watch over the well-being of her children. She started selling the curd and cream on the streets but, seeing a need for something more stable, she decided to obtain a site at the municipal market of Chichigalpa which is where she is currently located.

Today, the challenge facing Danelia is the need to invest in the infrastructure of her business for which she has turned to CEPRODEL over the past two years. She is very happy with the loans that she has been granted because, through them, she has been able to improve her sales as well as the standard of living of her family who so needs your support.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La venta de cuajada y crema es el negocio al que muy esforzadamente se dedica la señora Maria Danelia N. R. , soltera y con un hijo que están en edad escolar. Desde joven tiene este negocio iniciándolo cuando se separa de su esposo y comienza a velar por el bienestar de sus hijos. Inicia vendiendo en las calles las cuajadas y las cremas pero al ver la necesidad de algo mas estable, decide solicitar un tramo en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa que es donde actualmente se encuentra ubicada.

Hoy en día la problemática que atraviesa la señora Danelia es que necesita invertir en la infraestructura de su negocio y para ello ha recurrido a CEPRODEL desde hace 2 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados porque a través de ellos ha logrado mejorar sus ventas y sacar adelante su familia que tanto necesita de su apoyo.

loans.use: Purchase primary ingredients to prepare curds and cream (for making cheese).

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa has successfully accessed loans from SMT 7 times.  She sells rice, peppers, and pigeon peas.  Before the loans, Hawa had only 1 bag of rice as her stock, but now she can purchase up to 8 bags and has diversified her business.  She is now confident she can expand the business and is requesting a loan of $1200.  The 48-year-old widow will be able to earn more income to educate her 5 children.

loans.use: Hawa is well on her way to achieving a sustainable business.  She has invested all her loans wisely in her business, and has managed it well.  She needs another larger loan to continue with her planned expansion.

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun C. and her husband have been married since 1993. They have four children; three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school and the youngest one stays at home. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Thoeun has been growing vegetables and raising pigs for fifteen years. She grows many kinds of vegetables in the farm near her house. Her husband helps with the farming and also runs a motor taxi business.

Mrs. Thoeun is requesting a loan for the second time in the amount of $1,000 to fill in the land around her house and to purchase material to help raise the pigs.

loans.use: To fill in the land around the house and to raise pigs

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.ru:
Gulchehra D. is a widow. Her husband passed away three years ago and she was left alone with 2 children. In order to provide for her family she decided to go into sales. Despite all the hardships Gulchehra remained optimistic. She has been working in sales for the past 3 years, but she does not have enough funds to be able to increase turnover. She would like to obtain a $1000 loan that will help her to do that. The loan will increase the amount of profit she receives from the business and help supply the local population with goods. She plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Давлятова Гулчехра вдова. Муж ее умер 3 года назад, и она осталась одна с двумя детьми. Из-за жизненных трудностей, ей пришлось заняться торговлей. Сейчас она занимается торговлей уже 3 года, но ей не хватает оборотной суммы, для того чтобы увеличитьтоварооборот. Сейчас она хочет получить кредит в размере 1000 долларов , который поможет ей в ее деле.Этим она увеличит доход и обеспечит население товаром. Погасить кредит она сможет в течение 12 месяцев. Не смотря, на все трудности в ее жизни Гулчехра осталась такой же веселой и жизнерадостной.

loans.use: Increase turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her inventory for her housewares business

loans.name: Phen

texts.en: Phen R., age 44, is a widow and lives with her children in Phnom Penh. She has a business renting rooms to the garment workers, typically earning around $7 each day. She has a few rooms and the rent ranges from US$25 up to US$45 each month. Phen has five children, one of whom is married and no longer lives with her. To contribute to the family's daily income, Phen is supported by her daughter name Duk Keo Lina, who works in a restaurant, and makes around $5 per day. Phen still has two nieces who are under her care as well. To rent more rooms to the garment workers, she would like a loan to build more rooms. ( Mrs. Phen is pictured inside her house.)

loans.use: To build rooms to rent.

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma has had her business selling chickens for 8 years. She is married and has eight children, three of whom help her with her chicken sales. She sells in a market where her clients seek her out day-to-day to buy her chicken. Irma is very happy with the help that she has received, and she is going to invest the money she receives from this loan to buy more chickens to sell. In the future, she would like to open another shop where her children can also sell chicken.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow.

Irma lleva 8 años en el negocio, es casada, tiene 8 hijos, de los cuales 3 le ayudan en el negocio de la venta de pollo, ella vende en el interior de un mercado, donde la clientela la busca día con día, para poder comprarle, ella esta muy contenta con la ayuda que recibirá, ya que con el dinero que reciba, lo estará invirtiendo en mas compra de pollo, para tener en su venta, además ella a un futuro quiere colocar otra venta de pollo para que las hijas la puedan atender.

loans.use: To buy more chicken to sell

loans.name: Khoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeurn P. and her husband, Mr. Hong Sor, are fishermen in Thmey Village in Kandal Province. Aside from this business, Mrs. Khoeurn P. grows corn. In the fish business, Mrs. Khoeurn P. and her husband now cannot go to gather fish because their boat is too old. Thus, Mrs. Khoeurn P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat to start her business again, and she would use the rest of the loan to purchase a motor for the boat. Mrs. Khoeurn P. is 41 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another one is a fisherman. The remaining two are attending school. Mrs. Khoeurn P. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a new boat and a motor for it.

loans.name: Mele

texts.fr:
Née le 07 octobre 1977 à Lomé au TOGO, Madame MELE Z. est une femme très dynamique spécialisée dans la commercialisation des céréales depuis plus de cinq ans. Elle a deux personnes à charge.

Ne disposant pas d’important fonds de commerce, elle ne parvient pas à satisfaire la forte demande de sa clientèle. Aussi, ne parvient elle pas à dégager un bénéfice substantiel lui permettant de répondre aux besoins de sa famille.

Dans la perspective d’augmenter son pouvoir d’achat, aux fins de maximiser de bénéfices, elle sollicite un crédit.
texts.en:
Born in Lomé (Togo) on October 7, 1977, Mrs. Mele Z. is a very energetic woman who's been specializing in cereals sales for more than five years. She has two people to support. Because of her lack of capital, she cannot meet the high customer demand. Therefore, she does not manage to make enough profit to provide for her family. In view of maximizing her profit, she's seeking this loan to bolster her purchasing power.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell corn

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Monsieur G. Komi, est né le 28 Novembre 1987 à Agoè-Nyivé (Lomé). Instruit de niveau secondaire, il raccrocha très tôt les études pour céder à sa passion de commerce. Devenu ainsi un commerçant, il gère un établissement qu’il a co-ouvert avec sa sœur. Aujourd’hui ayant détaché son activité, il cherche un financement pour acheter et vendre des fournitures scolaires aux élèves de sa localité. Les bénéfices lui serviront d’étendre le cadre de son activité.
texts.en:
Mr.Komi G. was born on November 28,1987 in Agoè-Nyivé (Lomé). Having a secondary school education, he hung up his bookbag very early on in order to submit to his passion for commerce. Having thus become a merchant, he manages an establishment that he and his sister opened. Today, having let loose his work, he is seeking financing for doing commerce in school supplies for pupils in his town. The profits will serve to expand the scope of his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell school supplies

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana tiene 26 años, es soltera y vive en casa de su abuelita y su tía. Es natural de la ciudad de Arequipa, vino a Puno hace 2 años por su profesión de cosmeatra para progresar en esta ciudad, dedicándole todo su tiempo a la venta de productos de belleza. El negocio es muy rentable, ya que Ana con su facilidad de palabra y mucha alegría persuade a su clientela a adquirir sus productos de belleza.
No se le hace difícil su trabajo, más bien lo disfruta al máximo, ya que le gusta ayudar a  exteriorizar la belleza que sus clientas poseen. Este es su primer préstamo en Microfinanzas Prisma. Con el dinero, Ana aumentara su stock para mejorar su venta, lograr mejores ingresos y así lograr todas sus metas.
texts.en:
Ana is 26 years old, single, and lives with her grandmother and aunt. She was born in Arequipa and came to Puno 2 years ago in order to grow her business selling cosmetics in this city, dedicating all her time to selling beauty products. The business is very profitable, as Ana easily chats with others, is very happy, and easily persuades her clientele to purchase her beauty products. She doesn’t find her work difficulty, and she enjoys it to the maximum as she likes to help bring out the beauty her clients possess. This is her first loan with Microfinanzas Prisma. With the money Ana will increase her stock to improve her sales, obtain better income, and in this way achieve her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase her stock of beauty supplies

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort Y. is a mother of two kids who are currently in school. She is 34 year old trader. She trades in lace materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations.  For lack of adequate working capital, Comfort buys few stocks of lace materials and sells through hawking. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk of lace materials and textile clothes. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with quality education. Comfort belongs to the community group called Ephesians Trust group. The group members guarantee a loan through repayment pledge and support one another to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of lace materials and textile

loans.name: Saul Alberto

texts.es:
Saúl es socio del Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro  
Saúl es conviviente tiene 25 años dos hijos de 4 y 6 años, los dos están en el colegio.
Hace  cuatro años  se dedica  a la fabricación de muebles, trabaja solo y su taller funciona en su casa, su mercadería la vende en el parque industrial de Villa el Salvador, es proveedor de las tiendas grandes de muebles.  
Saúl necesita un crédito de 400 soles para la compra de materiales (napa picadillo) para la fabricación de los  muebles. 
El sueño de Saúl es darles lo mejor a su familia, tener un local propio que sea grande para vender sus productos que fabrico.
texts.en:
Saúl is a member of the Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro (Women of the Future). He is 25 years old, lives with his partner, and has two children, aged 4 and 6, who are both in school. For the last four years he has worked on his own building furniture and his workshop serves as his home. He sells his merchandise in the industrial park Villa el Salvador, providing the larger stores with his furniture. Saúl needs a 400 loan to buy raw materials to build more furniture. His dream is to provide a better life for his family, and to have his own locale big enough to build and sell his products.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Saúl needs a 400 soles loan to buy raw materials.

loans.name: Jameo's Group

texts.en:
Jameo N., commonly known as ‘Hajat,’ is the chairperson of Mumuwa development group in Mpigi. She has been a poultry farmer ever since she joined her lending group and she is happy that she has been able to sustain herself and her business all this while.

Jameo also buys agricultural products such as avocadoes, yellow bananas, jackfruit, oranges, and mangoes from farmers in and around her village and takes them to Kampala for sale. This is a seasonal business and profitable since there is a ready market for all that she takes for sale. Jameo has booked more layers and broilers from a poultry farm hence she needs a loan to be able to pay up the balance and also buy start-up feed for the chickens. She is grateful for the loans because they have made her who she is today.

loans.use: pay for the day-old chicks that she has ordered as well as stocking feed for them

loans.name: Saifullo

texts.en:
Saifullo A. is 42 years old. He is married with three children. He and his family live in Khujand city. Saifullo rents a minivan and offers transportation services. His business is the only source of income for the family. Saifullo has been in this business for 18 years and has gained rich experience on driving. To be able to decrease the expenses for  fuel and consequently to reduce the fees for his services, Saifullo is planning to replace the fuel supply system on his minivan. He is requesting a loan of $800 USD. Saifullo thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in 12 months.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key place along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To a new fuel supply system for his minivan

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
la Sra. Maria M. tiene una pulperia desde hace 4 años, la cual opera bajo el nombre de pulperia MARY CARMEN, su negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitacion, ella es casada y madre de dos hijos de los cuales su hija es la que depende totalmente de ellos dos, el otro esta casado y vive en otro lugar con su esposa.
el esposo de Maria se dedica al comercio tiene una agropecuaria y tambien es productor de cafe.
la sra. Maria nos conto que esta bien alegre ya que su negocio es una bendicion de Dios, ya que con los ingresos que ella ha tenido a podido invertir el dinero en su casa y en su negocio, ahorita ella quiere invertir en su negocio para tener mas variedad de productos y asi poder cumplir con las exigencias de todos sus clientes. por tal razon esta solicitando el credito y espera que en un futuro su negocio sea un mini market.
texts.en:
Maria M. has had a grocery store for four years, called "Pulperia Mary Carmen". It is located in a room in her house.

She is married and has two children. Her daughter is still dependent while her son is married and lives elsewhere with his wife. Maria's husband raises livestock and also grows coffee. Maria is very pleased since her business is a blessing from God; it has enabled her to invest in her house and business.

Now she wants to expand her product range to be able to cater to all her customers' demands. This is the reason for requesting the loan; in the future, she would like to expand her business to become a mini-market.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Butter, sugar, rice, beans, toilet paper, soft drinks, cookies, bread, soap, cream, deodorants.

loans.name: Boeb

texts.en: Boeb M., 34, lives with his family in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. He has three children, two of whom are married and live independently. Boeb earns a living planting crops, and his wife helps him with this physical work. He also sells carving wood from his home as another source of income. In this way he can earn $3 a day to provide for his family's needs. With the crop-growing season approaching, Boeb M. wants to borrow $200 USD to buy seed for growing corn, and with the rest of the loan he intends to increase his stocks of carving wood.

loans.use: To buy seed for growing corn, and stocks of carving wood

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia N. is 30 years old. She is married and mother of one child (a girl). She lives with her husband and the children. Currently her child is in school in the community where they live in the eastern region of Ghana. Her husband is a diamond miner. They live in a community endowed with natural resources like gold and diamonds.

Leticia is a local manufacturer of Soaps. She combines materials like palm oil, soda powder, cocoa pods and coconut oil to create her soaps. Leticia has ten years experience in soap manufacturing. She is not able to produce in large quantities for lack of funds to buy raw materials. She wants to take advantage of the loan facility to buy more raw materials and processing equipment to scale up production. She hopes to increase her income to support her children's education. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Hannah Mma’ which means Hannah’s children.

loans.use: To scale up production of soaps

loans.name: Patricia Del Socorro

texts.es: La señora Patricia del Socorro M., tiene la edad de 30 años, habita en el barrio San Francisco, ubicado en el municipio de Nidirí, junto a su esposo en el trabaja para apoyarle con los gastos del hogar, ellos tiene a su cargo un hijo de siete años, los planes hacia su familia es poder mejorar las condiciones de vida y vivir dignamente, ella desde hace 20 años, se dedica a los trabajos agrícolas, con sus propios esfuerzos y el de su papá ha logrado sacar producción , pero con resultados no factibles , ya que estos carecen de fertilizantes e insumos . Lo cual con el financiamiento obtenido van a comprar dicho fertilizantes, esperando con esto poder tener mejores resultado en la producción, da las gracias a la institución por hacer posible estas mejoras.
texts.en:
Patricia del Socorro M. is 30 years old and lives in the San Francisco neighborhood in Nidirí. She and her husband work together to cover their living expenses. They have a seven-year-old son. She would like to improve their living conditions and live decently. She has been working as in agriculture for 20 years. She and her father have had some production success, but it is unsustainable without fertilizers and other supplies. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers, with the hope of achieving better results. She is grateful to the organization for making this progress possible.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies and fertilizer to improve production

loans.name: Antonio De Jesus

texts.es: El señor Antonio de Jesús A. tiene  36 años de edad, reside en el barrio Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, su esposa es ama de casa,  le tiene cinco hijos todos a su cargo y cursando sus estudios, don Antonio se desempeña como mecánico desde hace cinco años, inicio este negocio con prestamos financieros, este es su cuarto ciclo en Afodenic el cual va invertir en la compra de herramientas, para dar un mejor servicios a sus clientes. Sus planes a futuro es mejorar la infraestructura del local de trabajo, da las gracias a ala institución por los beneficios adquiridos en su vida personal como para su familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Antonio de Jesús A. is 36 years old and lives in the North Laureles neighborhood in the capital of Nicaragua, Managua. His wife is a housewife and she takes care of their five children. All of their children are in school. Don Antonio has been making a living as a mechanic at his own shop for the past 5 years. He started his business with a loan and he is now taking out his fourth loan through Afodenic. He will invest the money from this loan in purchasing tools so that he can serve his clients better. His future plans are to make improvements to his shop. He is thankful for the help that Afordenic has given to him and for the positives things that it has brought him and his family.

(Translated by Tyler of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase new tools so that he can better serve his clients.

loans.name: Ama Amétowayona

texts.fr: Cette jeune femme a très tôt abandonné les études, devant subvenir à ses propres besoins, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de produits alimentaires dans le quartier de hedzranawoé, beaucoup de ses clients apprécient ses services. Sa clientèle grandit elle voudrait mieux les accueillir et sollicite pour le faire de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter  4 sacs de riz , 2 sacs de gari, des huiles "NIOTO" et divers produits alimentaires
texts.en:
This young woman left school early on. Since she had to support herself, she went into selling foodstuffs in the Hedzranawoé neighborhood; many of her customers are grateful for her service. Her clientele is growing and she would like to welcome them all, so she is asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 4 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of "gari" (manioc grits), NIOTO brand oils, and various other foodstuffs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A., forty years old, is a petty trader and married with four children. Three of her children are currently in school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother. Mary helps her husband in providing for the household through the sale of used bags.

Selling of used bags is a big market in Ghana, since brand new bags are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore, selling of used bags has created a market for many Ghanaian women like Mary. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used bags and shoes to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her to save more for her children’s education and also to rent a store to work in.

loans.use: To buy second-hand bags and shoes

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.en:
Bakhtiyor is a young and energetic man with the desire to improve his family's living conditions. He is 22 years old and lives in Spitamen, Tajikistan. He has a retail shop where he sells spare parts for foreign cars. He has been involved in this business for more than 5 years, since before, he has helped his father. He provides cars with spare parts and his family with the necessary food and other needs.

Bakhtiyor has a great demand for spare parts thus he wants to buy more goods in order to hold on to his clients. He wants to take out an individual loan of 3000 Somoni to buy more spare parts and enlarge his shop inventory.

Bakhtiyor is happy about this loan and would like to thank everyone for their trust and support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for cars to sell

loans.name: Maria Esperanza

texts.es: Doña Maria de 36 años de edad, es una ejecutiva de venta de la emprea óptica de Guadalupe de Hondura y el Salvador, tiene tres años laborando en esta empresa, reside en Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, tiene dos hijos de que estudian, sus planes es poder terminar de construir su casa ya que es muy sencilla, sus paredes son de zinc que esta muy viejo e insegura para su familia y como es madre soltera no ha tenido el apoyo del padre de los niños. Con este crédito comprara materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento y verjas para hacer la casa e ir poco a poco mejorando. Y lograr tener una casa digna.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria is 36 years old and is an executive in an optical business called “Guadalupe of Honduras and El Salvador”. She has been working in this business for three years. She lives in North Laurel in the capital of Managua. She has three children that study. She plans to finish building her house. She has a simple house with zinc walls that are very old and not very stable for a family. She is a single mother that does not have the support of her children’s father. With this loan she will buy construction materials such as stone, sand, cement and gates to make a house. Little by little things will improve. She would like to have a worthy home.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials so that she can build a concrete home.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina D., from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City, is a 40-year-old married mother of six school-aged children. To make a living, Dina buys and sells bananas, coconuts and cassava. Engaged in her business for over four years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

Dina wants to open up a mini grocery store so as to have another income for her family. In 2008, she joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI, she is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to invest in starting the grocery store business. This loan will be Dina's fourth from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family income and support her children's education.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To start a mini grocery store.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ma. Aida

texts.en:
Along with her 23-year-old son, 52-year-old Ma. Aida S. lives with her 27-year-old daughter’s family. Early this year, she joined ASHI to get access to credit for financing a business for her son so he could have his own source of income.  Ma. Aida knew that his employment and income opportunities would be limited because of his limited education.  By providing him with a business to run for himself, she knew that he would be able to earn income everyday.  Ma. Aida is less worried about her daughter since she has a husband to support her.

Ma. Aida’s first loan in ASHI was used as a down payment (initial payment) for the motorcycle she bought for her son to use for a taxi hire business (which is commonly called “habal-habal” in the province dialect).  Everyday, Ma. Aida’s son can earn a minimum of Php100 profit, which he gave to Ma. Aida to pay for monthly amortization on the motorcycle.  Ma. Aida has her own income being a village faith healer. 

Over six months, Ma. Aida was able to repay her first loan and now she requests for a much larger loan to be used in paying her motorcycle’s amortization in advance, so she can be less worried each month.

loans.use: To make payments on the motorcycle used for a taxi business.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana A., married with five dependents, received education through senior high school.  Christiana has been selling baked bread and a locally-made cocoa drink near Nyankumasi since 2004. She uses her income to support her husband, who is a builder, in the payment of utility bills.  Christiana will use the loan to purchase maize and sugar and other baking ingredients. With the new profits from her expanded business, Christiana plans to save to further expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase maize and sugar and other baking ingredients

loans.name: Janepher Namutebi 's Group

texts.en: Janepher is 34 year married with four children aged between 6 and 12 .All her children go to school .She resides and rents a two roomed house where she stays with six people  The family has access to electricity and no piped water and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala. Janepher has a stall selling Newspapers in Makerere Kikoni and buys these news papers from distributors and so she doesn’t incur extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She doesn’t pay rent for her business as she works from her home. Janepher sells to all categories of people both on retail and whole sale Janepher has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for one year servicing her third loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy newspapers varieties and magazines. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a distributing van.

loans.use: To buy more newspapers and magazines

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma J. is from the village of Tuburan. She is 37 years old and married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns and operates a business raising hogs to sell. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 45000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gemma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 45000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and to build shelters for her livestock. This will be her fifth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase feed and to build shelters for her livestock

loans.name: Janet Nakabugo's Group

texts.en:
Janet owns a restaurant selling all types of food near the main hospital (Mulago), in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She sells both retail and wholesale. Janet works seven days a week. She serves an average of 25 customers a day. Her major business challenges include thieves, the ever increasing prices of foodstuffs due to the persistent drought in banana-growing areas, and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her. She incurs additional transport costs buying foodstuff from Kalerwe market (one of the busiest markets in Uganda).

Janet is 40. None of her children go to school, only her grandchildren. Two of them go to school. The older children got pregnant and dropped out of school. She owns a one-room house where she lives with three people. Janet also takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity or piped water, but gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.

Janet has been in her business for over ten years, and with MCDT for 12 years – now on her 20th loan working with the same group mates. Janet joined MCDT because it is near her home and also because she likes working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, a sack of rice, Irish potatoes and maize flour. She hopes to see her business get bigger and to start an outside catering section.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant like bananas, Irish potatoes, rice and maize flour

loans.name: Desireeh

texts.en:
Desireeh and her husband are working hard to earn a living for their family in order to overcome the difficulties in life, to support their daily needs, and also to send their children to school. They want them to finish their studies in college so that they will have good jobs someday.

Desireeh’s husband works as a tricycle operator in Tuguegarao City, while Desireeh manages a small sari-sari store (community based store) in front of their house selling different grocery items. Since their children are not yet enrolled in college, she needs to earn a higher income to support their daily basic needs. Therefore, Desireeh decided to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders. She is requesting Php5,000 to purchase additional merchandise for her store. She hopes that her plan will succeed through her patience and sacrifices.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more stock of bicycle and motorbike spare parts

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 34 years old, married and the mother of six school aged children.  She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana.  Mary works hard to provide for her family. She is a trader of game meat, buying freshly hunted game from local hunters.  Mary smokes and supplies the meat to vendors in her community. Mary has been in business for fifteen years and wants a loan to procure meat in bulk. It is her desire to give all of her children a good education.

loans.use: Buy game meat.

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
El señor Francisco Javier H. está muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito, el cual le ayudo adquirí su vivienda sus familia ya tiene un lugar seguro donde vivir. 
Esta solicitando nuevamente su cooperación para este préstamo ya que le esta haciendo falta algunos muebles a su casa, lo que más le interesa es poner los muebles de la cocina, ya que por el momento no cuenta con ellos. 
Planea pagar el crédito con su ingreso que obtiene de su trabaja en una compañía de limpieza. Desea que su familia tenga comodidad en su casa. 
La persona que aparece en la foto la señora Lucero Sánchez y su pequeño hijo, familia del señor Francisco. Ya que el día de la visita se encontraba en su trabajo.
texts.en:
Francisco Javier H. is very grateful for the help he got with his previous loan, which helped him buy his own home; his family now has a safe place to live. He is asking for funding again because his house lacks furniture; what he's most interested in is kitchen furniture since he doesn't have any at present. He intends to repay the loan with earnings from his work for a cleaning company. He wants his family to be comfortable at home. The person in the photo is Lucero Sánchez and their son, Francisco's family; on home visit day he was away at work.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen furniture.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a 36-year-old married woman with five children, three of whom attend school. She has been running her snack shop for two years and employs two people. Previously, she was employed as a telephone operator.

With the kes 30,000 loan, Catherine wants to expand her business. She describes herself as active and hardworking.

loans.use: To expand her snacks business

loans.name: Olexander

texts.en:
Olexander is married with three children: two boys and a girl. He is a farmer from Gladkovka. Olexander grows early spring agricultural produce for further sale in regional marketplaces. He has been in this business for 20 years. Currently, Olexander has 15,000 Grivnyas invested in this trade.  

Olexander is seeking an 8,000 Grivnya loan to purchase polyethylene film, coir fiber pads, fertilizers and firewood for his greenhouse. He can be characterized as an organized and diligent planner. These natural characteristics have helped him develop his venture and thus provide for his family needs.

loans.use: to purchase polyethylene film, coir fiber pads, fertilizers and firewood for his greenhouse

loans.name: Las Dulces Group

texts.es: Las características del banco comunal  “Las Dulces” esta representadas por la señora Julia  y conformada por 16 miembros  todos residentes de la  misma zona. La señora Julia tiene dos hijos en edad escolar y hace poco su esposo quedo sin trabajo por lo que se vio en la necesidad de trabajar pero como ella no cuenta con ninguna experiencia en otro tipo de trabajos se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catálogos con marcas de Avon, Esika, Yambal y todo lo que se pueda vender a domicilio, vendiendo en el colegio de sus hijos, y empresas privadas donde ya ha conseguido clientela, actualmente su esposo ya consiguió trabajo pero la señora Julia desea seguir trabajando para ayudar a sus hijos a forjar con estudios un mejor futuro es por esta razón que requiere de capital para obtener productos de oferta y llevar directo productos atractivos para sus clientes. El resto de sus compañeras se dedican a la venta de hamburguesa, venta de pan, venta de comida, venta de productos de cosméticos. La competencia entre las socias es realmente difícil, especialmente en la venta de comida y en la venta de cosméticos, ya que cada socia espera cada día un buen resultado en sus ventas. El crédito lo destinaran para poder surtir sus tiendas y comprar más productos y ofrecer mejores servicios a sus clientes para que a futuro tengan sus negocios con mayores ingresos y una mejor situación económica. Como es un grupo nuevo se les ha dado una capacitación que están satisfechas y contentas de ser clientes de Agrocapital  pero algunas de las socias ya poseen experiencia gracias a créditos similares en otras entidades
texts.en:
Julia represents the communal bank "Las Dulces," which is made up of 16 members who all live in the same neighborhood. Julia has 2 school-aged children and recently her husband lost his job, and for this reason she saw the necessity of working. But she did not have any kind of experience, so she began to sell Avon, Esika, Yambal and other brand cosmetics through catalogs from her home, as well as at the school of her children and at private companies where she has gotten customers. Now her husband found work, but Julia wants to keep working to help her sons forge ahead with their education so they can have a better future. For this reason she needs capital to buy products to offer, and to bring appealing products directly to her customers. The rest of her fellow bank members sell hamburgers, bread, meals, and cosmetics. The competition amongst the members is very difficult, especially in the areas of food sales and cosmetics, as each member hopes each day to have a good result with their sales. This loan will be used to restock their businesses with more products, so that they can offer better service to their customers and so that their businesses will provide higher incomes in the future and a better economic situation. As this is a new group, they have been given training, and they are very pleased and content to be clients of Agrocapital. Some of the members already have experience thanks to similar loans from other organizations.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy products to restock their businesses

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura J. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Ori. She is 35 years old. Laura is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Laura owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. Laura has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Laura joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Laura is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Laura from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora L. is from the village of Duka, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Leonora is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Leonora owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop which sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Chun D. is married with three teenage kids; all three are no longer in school and work in the construction field. Her husband is a fisherman.

Chun D. gets her daily income from selling fish. She gets the fish from her husband’s fishing work. Chun D. requests a loan to add to her small savings in order to buy an old motorbike that she will use to deliver the fish to the market.

loans.use: To buy an old motorbike for delivering fish to the market

loans.name: Twegatte Women's Group, Kampala

texts.en:
Her fifteen-year-old tailoring business has stood her in such good stead in her locality that laurels coming her way have been inevitable. 38-year-old K. Sarah began as a home-based seamstress until she realized her trade could bring her long drawn out financial dividends.

The future business prospects for this married mother of two are looking good, going by the 400,000 shillings Sarah makes in a month and the experience she has now gained. Her business has seen success in subsequent years because of the demand by many people for traditional wear, clothes she starting making five years ago.

Sarah’s two children have both completed school, courtesy of her business. Throughout these fifteen years in business, her reliable recourse has invariably been her good customer care skills.

With this loan, Sarah is upbeat with conviction that she will be able to buy some additional sewing machines to add to those she already has.

loans.use: To purchase additional sewing machines for her business

loans.name: Jessie Isabel

texts.en: Jessie Isabel D. is from the village of North Park Area, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 58 years old, is widowed, and has four adult children. Jessie Isabel owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Jessie Isabel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Jessie Isabel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: North Park Area, Wao, Lanao de Sur

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida S., 31, has been managing her own junk shop for quite some time now. She is married to Liberato S. Jr. and they are blessed with six children. She is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Loida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow 11 times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her junk shop.

To ensure the success of her business, Loida would like to apply for a 10,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital to buy junk from collectors and sell it to bigger foundries. Loida dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She hopes that her family will continue to grow in God’s love.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy junk from collectors to sell to bigger foundries

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy L. is a 40-year-old married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She has an 11-year-old child, who is currently in school.

To earn a living, Amy works in the farming industry. Specifically, she plants and harvests rice crops, and she has been doing this for more than thirteen years now. Amy explains that loans through CEVI have immensely helped her improve her business. At present, she needs seeds, fertilizers, and other farming tools, which is why she is applying for another loan from CEVI. Indeed, she is now requesting a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($350). She also hopes to buy a piglet, which she could feed and ultimately re-sell, to general additional income.

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing additional seeds, fertilizers, and other farming necessities

loans.name: Yanaturo Alto  ( Cuenca ) Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal Yanaturo Alto está formado por 14 mujeres luchadoras  que  día a día con su trabajo buscan  mejorar su económica, viven en la comunidad de Yanaturo  que se caracteriza por sus bellos paisajes; gran parte de su gente  se dedica a la elaboración de sombreros de paja toquilla, mucha de su población busca en la ciudad la oportunidad de un mejor trabajo.

La Señora Rosario C. es socia del banco comunal Yanaturo, tiene 59 años de edad, es viuda hace 18 años y tiene 5 hijos los cuales todos son casados y viven independientemente con sus familias, gracias a su trabajo y esfuerzo ha logrado construir su casa propia aunque es una pequeña casita. Nuestra socia se dedica a la cría de pollos hace 2 años y también atiende en su tienda, la misma que tiene 15 años, labora todo el día y en sus tiempos libres trabaja en la agricultura cultivando su propio terreno,la producción es para el consumo de su hogar. Es su primer crédito, fue invitada por una amiga que pertenece a la banco comunal, su crédito va a invertir en la compra de pollos y también para realizarse un chequeo médico.  Su meta es seguir creciendo en su tienda.

La Señora María B. se encuentra el la banco comunal hace 4 ciclos, fue  invitada por una amiga. Se dedica a la cría de pollos, los mismos que los vende pelados o vivos según como le pidan sus clientes, inicio este  negocio con el primer crédito que realizo. Nuestra socia tiene 22 años de edad,  vive en unión libre y fruto de su unión tiene una hija  de un año ocho meses, su esposo trabaja en una empresa que realizan instalaciones de agua y gas, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando. Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de pollos. Su meta es llegar a tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
The Yanaturo community bank is made up of 14 hardworking women who strive day to day to improve their economic situation. They live in Yanaturo, which is known for its beautiful scenery and where a large number of residents make a living weaving straw hats. A large portion of the population also seek opportunities in the city. Rosario C. is a partner in the Yanaturo community bank, is 59, widowed 18 years ago, and has 5 children that are all married and live independently. Thanks to her work and effort she has been able to build a small home of her own. She has made a living raising chickens for the past 2 years as well as helping customers in the store she has had for 15 years. She works all day and in her off time she cultivates her own lands, which is for her own consumption. This is her first loan; she was invited by a friend and member of the community bank. Her loan will be invested in purchasing chickens as well as getting a medical check-up. Her goal is to keep growing her store business. Maria B. has been in the community bank for 4 loan cycles; she was invited by a friend. She raises chickens, which she sells plucked or alive according to her customers' orders. She started the business with the first loan she took out. She is 22 years old and lives with her partner, which whom she has an 8-month-old daughter. Her husband works for a company that installs water and gas lines. They do not own their own home; they rent. She plans to use this loan to buy more chickens. Her goal is to own her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chickens/ medical checkup.

loans.name: Khassama Aïdara Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité KHASSAMA AÏDARA est créé en juin 2010 lors de la scission du Banc Villageois de TOUB. SERAS. Il est composé de 12 femmes du même village qui se sont organisées par affinité et par voisinage.

Madame NDEYE F., la femme dont le visage est mis en médaillon en haut à gauche de la photo est la responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 54 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants et a la charge de ses deux petits enfants. 

Elle fait de l'embouche ovine depuis plus de 5 ans. Elle a acquière une bonne expérience de cette activité.

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter 05 moutons. Elle les embouchera pendant au moins 5 mois avant de les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité.

Elle soutien son mari dans la prise en charge des besoins de la famille. Elle compte également renforcer son niveau d'épargne
texts.en:
The Khamassa Aïdara solidarity group was created in June 2010 when the TouB. Seras « Banc Villageois » loan group was dissolved. It consists of 12 women from the same village who got together through personal affinities and as neighbors. Mrs. Ndeye F. is responsible for the group: her face is shown in a medallion in the upper left of the picture. She is 54 years old, married, the mother of eight children, and has her two grand-children under her care. She has been fattening sheep for the past five years, and has acquired a solid experience in this activity. Her new loan will enable her to buy five sheep. She will fatten them for at least five months before reselling them at local markets in her area. She assists her husband in taking care of family expenses. She also intends to strengthen her level of savings.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sheep

loans.name: Raya

texts.en:
Raya H. is 51 years old and comes from a large but humble family. She is married and the loving mother of two children. She is a nurse in local hospital but her salary is too small and she needed additional financial support. In 2004 she started a poultry breeding business and now it is her main source of income. 

Now Raya dedicates herself to raising poultry and cattle, and with the income she generates, she provides a better quality of life for her children. Her monthly profit is about 150-200 Azerbaijani manat (AZN) and she would like to increase it. Her permanent clients demand is meat and she is going to purchase more cattle and chicken. 

Raya is asking for a 900 AZN loan in order to buy more young cattle and poultry to later sell when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: purchase calves and poultry

loans.name: Maluay De Curiquinga (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Maluay de Curiquinga se encuentra formado por 12 mujeres que viven el la comunidad del mismo nombre que es perteneciente a la parroquia del Valle, esta parroquia es de clima frió, la agricultura y la ganadería son las actividades tradicionales de su gente. La mayor parte de la población sale por las mañanas a trabajar en la ciudad de Cuenca y retorna por las tardes;  Ocupándose en diferentes actividades económicas. Nuestras socias trabajan en diferentes actividades pero todas con un mismo fin que es  salir  adelante con  sus familias y ofrecerles un mejor futuro.

La Señora. Carmen Isabel C. vive en la comunidad de Conchan del Milagro que es perteneciente a la parroquia del Valle. Este es el tercer crédito que realiza en la fundación, los mismos que le han beneficiado  en su pequeño negocio. Es de profesión costurera aprendió esta actividad hace 5 años y fue una amiga quien le ha enseñado  esta actividad, ahora labora en su casa en su pequeño taller junto a su esposo que ejerce la misma profesión, realizan todo tipo de costuras y arreglos, no tienen horario de trabajo y laboran de lunes a sábado, dedicándose el día domingo a la familia.
Doña Carmen  es muy joven con apenas 23 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos, uno de  2 años  y otro de 4 meses, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en una casa que su mamá les ha prestado. El  dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de una nueva maquina de coser que les hace falta. Su meta es terminar sus estudios del colegio ya que llego a cursar hasta el quinto año.

La Señora Rosa Aurora Q. vive en la comunidad de Maluay de Curiquinga, que perteneciente a la parroquia del Valle. Nuestra socia tiene 49 años, es casada y tiene 10 hijos, sus tres primeros hijos son casados y viven  independientemente, sus hijos solteros tienen  27, 17, 15, 13, 11, 10 y 5 años de edad, su hija de 27 y su hijo de 13 años pasan en la casa ayudando a los quehaceres, sus hijos de 17 y 15 años trabajan y ayudan a la economía del hogar y sus tres últimos hijos  estudian en una escuelita de la localidad, su esposo pasa en la casa ya que es de avanzada edad, con el trabajo conyugal ha logrado construir su casa propia.
La Señora Rosa se dedica al trabajo que le han inculcado sus padres que es la agricultura, labra sus propias tierras en donde siembra maíz, papas, etc., que es para su consumo y algo vende, también se dedica  a la cría de chanchos y cuyes a los que los vende en su propia comunidad. Este es el segundo crédito que realiza en la banca comunal y  está muy contenta ya que los créditos le están beneficiando en su hogar, el nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de una vaca. Su sueño es seguir conservando la salud.
texts.en:
The Maluay de Curiquinga communal bank is made up of 12 women who live in the community of the same name. It’s part of the Valle parish, which has a cold climate. Farming and raising livestock are its people’s traditional occupations. Most of the population goes out in the mornings, to work in the city of Cuenca, to work various trades, and returns in the evening. Our associates work different trades, but with the same goal; to get their families ahead and offer them a better future. Carmen Isabel C. lives in the Conchan del Milagro community, which is a part of the Valle parish. This will be her third loan through the foundation. The prior ones have helped her small business. She is a seamstress who learned this trade five years ago when one of her friends taught her. She now works out of a small workshop in her home, alongside her husband who also works in this trade. They do all sorts of sewing and repairs. They don’t have a regular schedule, but they work Monday through Saturday. Sunday is a family day. Carmen is very young, barely 23. She is married and has two children, one is two years old and the other is four months old. They don’t have a house of their own yet, so they live in a house that her mother loaned them. She will use the money from this loan to invest in a new sewing machine that they need. Her goal is to complete her collage education, now that she has completed five [out of six] years of study. Rosa Aurora Q. lives in the Maluay de Curiquinga community, which is a part of the Valle parish. She is 49 years old, is married and has 10 children. Her three oldest are married and on their own. Her single children are 27, 17, 15, 13, 11, 10, and 5. Her 27 year old daughter and her 13 year old son work in the home and help with the chores. Her 17 and 15 year old sons work and help with the household finances. Her three youngest attend the local school. Her husband stays home, now that he is of old age. They were able to have their house built by working together. Rosa works the trade that her parents gave her; farming. She works her own land, where she grows corn, potatoes, etc. Some of her harvest is for her own consumption and some she sells. She also raises hogs and Guinea pigs, which she sells to people in her community. This will be her second loan from the communal bank and she is happy about the loans that she has benefited from in her home. She will use the money from this loan to buy a cow. She wants to continue to stay in good health.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sewing machine / Cow

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Amor Y Paz se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Calderón de la  ciudad de Portoviejo, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos.

La señora Ana esta en el Banco Comunal desde sus inicios y le ha gustado tanto que ya son 12 años que es socia. Tiene 46 años y está casada hace 26 años, tiene tres hijos ya mayores de edad, su esposo se dedica al comercio.

Se dedica junto a su esposo al comercio en lo que es compra y venta de productos agrícolas, venden tamarindo cocinado por libras, maní en grano y molido, achiote y otros productos más, al por mayor y menor. Trabajan todos los días de 4 am hasta las 15h00 y cuando tiene que hacer recorridos hasta la noche, ya que además de entregar en la localidad, también se desplaza a otras ciudades, como Manta, Portoviejo y Quevedo. Los productos los compran a los agricultores de la zona. Los procesa u después los lleva a entregar.

Este crédito lo va a utilizar en comprar más productos para tener en reserva para cuando se escasee ya que son productos que se pueden guardar por un buen tiempo.

Sus metas son seguir adelante y quizás después comprar un carro para realizar sus ventas.
texts.en:
The Amor y Paz community bank meets every two weeks in the Calderon Parish in the town of Portoviejo. The townspeople are involved in agriculture, raising animals and selling their products. Ana has been with the bank since its inception. She has enjoyed been a partner for the last 12 years. She is 46 years old, has been married for 26 years and has three adult children. Her husband works in commerce. She works with her husband buying and selling produce. They sell cooked tamarind by the pound, ground and whole peanuts, achiote and others, retail and wholesale. They work every day from 4am to 3pm and until evening when they need to do deliveries. Besides delivering in town they also go to other towns such as Manta, Portoviejo and Quevedo. Local producers buy their products. They process the products and deliver them back. They will use the loan to purchase more products to have some in stock when supplies come down since these products can be stored for a good amount of time. Their goal is to strive ahead and maybe later buy a car to make their sales.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprar tamarind, peanuts, achiote, etc.

loans.name: Ossama

texts.ar: اسامه سيدة متزوجة تبلغ الخامسة والعشرون من العمر، لديها ولد واحد. تملك أسامة محل لبيع وتنسيق الازهارمنذ سنة ونصف. سبق لاسامة ان تعاملت مع المجموعة، وكان للقرض تاثير جيد على حياتها وعلى المستوى المعيشي لعائلتها، فقد ساعد على التوسع ةالإعتماد على النفس. ما يمييز عمل أسامة أنه متكامل وتفتح 24 ساعة، لتلبية حاجات ورغبات الأجناس المختلفة. فهي تلتزم تزيين الاعراس والسيارات، وتتمييز بذوقها الرفيع. زبائنها هم سكان المنطقة، أصحاب الفنادق والمطاعم، متعهدي الأفراح، بالإضافة إلى السياح. المشاكل التي واجهتها في بداية عملها هو عدم مصداقية التعامل من قبل الزيائن، ولكن إصرارها على النجاح ومثابرتها عليه أوصلها إلى ذروة النجاح. هذه المرة عمدت اسامه إلى طلب قرض من المجموعة لشراء كمية من الازهار الموسمية، بالإضافة إلى ستاندات أو رفوف لعرض البضائع بشكل احلى. تحلم وتصر اسامة على إنشاء مكتب تعهدات وإلتزام الأفراح.
texts.en: Ossama is a 25-year-old wife and mother of one who has for the last year-and-a-half been the owner of a florist shop. The last loan which Ossama received from Al-Majmoua improved the standard of living for her and her family by helping her expand her business and become more self-reliant. The applicant’s shop is distinguished by its owner’s exquisite taste as well as its 24-hour services ready to meet anyone’s needs. Among the larger orders the applicant fills are those for wedding flowers and decorating wedding caravans with flowers. The applicant’s patrons come from the general area and include hotel and restaurant owners, wedding providers, and tourists. The biggest obstacle which Ossama faced at the outset of her work was lack of name recognition, but her persistence has conveyed her to the peak of success. The applicant is now asking for a loan of $1500 to purchase seasonal flowers as well as stands and shelves to more aesthetically showcase her products. Ossama also hopes to eventually establish a wedding providing agency.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal flowers and stands and shelves to showcase products

loans.name: Maria Esmeralda

texts.en:
Maria, a 30-year-old single mother with a two-year-old daughter, lives in her parents' home along with her brothers and sisters. Her home, which is made of adobe and has limited access to utilities, is in Santa Rosa, a coastal city about 20 minutes from Chiclayo. Maria has lived there for 15 years.

For the last two years Maria has been selling beer and other beverages out of her home, purchasing her merchandise from wholesalers that pass through the area and then reselling her inventory at retail prices. This business yields a steady stream of income daily.

This will be Maria’s first loan with our institution. She plans to use the funds to expand her inventory and obtain greater discounts through bulk purchases. She hopes that the increase in income will allow her to grow her business and little by little improve the lifestyle of her family.

Maria is a very dedicated mother and is well-respected within the area. Her store is popular amongst the locals.

loans.use: To purchase additional beer and other beverages

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie P. is from the town of Banga. She is 36 years old. Rosalie is married and has three children, aged 17, 14 and 6. Rosalie grows pigs and also farms for a living. She sells the pigs to the market. She also helps her husband plant and harvest rice crops. Aside from the piggery and farm, she also runs a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells eggs, coffee and other kinds of products.

Rosalie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She said she likes its program, especially the micro insurance. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase farm supplies and feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and feeds

loans.name: Joana Ekua Yama

texts.en: Joana Ekua Yama M. sells fried fish at Abura. She is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a cleaner. Joana has been selling fried fish for four years. She assists her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to fry for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to further her children’s education.

loans.use: buy more fresh fish to fry for sale
